Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: Mr David Hawker) took the chair at 9.00 a.m. and read prayers. NA INFORMATION (CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS) AMENDMENT (APPLICATION) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: NATIONAL SECURITY
text: I move: That this bill be now read a second time. This bill amends the National Security Information (Criminal Proceedings) Act 2004. It seeks to clarify how the act applies to certain federal criminal proceedings. In particular, the bill reinforces the appliintent cation of the act to proceedings that commenced prior to 11 January 2005-that is, the day on which the main provisions of the act commenced. This amendment will ensure that the act can be applied to a number of terrorism related proceedings that are currently under way, once the prosecutor gives the requisite notice to the court and defendant. It was not intended that, simply because a person had been charged and a bail hearing had occurred before the commencement of the act on 11 January 2005, the act could not be applied to the committal or trial of the person some months or years later. However, this amendment will not give the act any retrospective effect. Rather, it simply ensures that the act can apply to the future stages of a proceeding that began before 11 January 2005. It will not affect anything that occurred before the notice was given. The bill also seeks to clarify how the act applies to any proceeding (including a proceeding which began after the act commenced) in which the prosecutor gives the requisite notice to the court and defendant after the proceeding commenced. This amendment restates the intent of the act to require a prosecutor to give the requisite notice only once, after which time the act will apply to all subsequent parts of the proceeding. It will not be necessary for the prosecutor to give notice in each subsequent part of the proceeding. Without these two clarifications, it is possible that the act may be subject to misinterpretation. In turn, this may jeopardise the underlying of the act-to facilitate the prosecution of an offence without risk to national security or a defendant's right to a fair trial. For this reason, I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr MCClelland) adjourned. NA AMENDMENT (EXTENDED NA UNION FEES) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Andrews, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: PROHIBITION OF COMPULSORY
text: Menzies-Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (9.04 a.m.)-I move: That this bill be now read a second time. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Extended Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2004 was introduced into the 40th Parliament. The bill lapsed with the dissolution of the parliament. The government is reintroducing this bill in line with the continthat ued commitment to the elimination of bargaining fees in industrial agreements. This government's commitment to the principle of freedom of association is a cornerstone of a workplace relations framework that is providing for more productive and more prosperous workplaces. The Workplace Relations Act 1996 reflects the principle of freedom of association with broad legislative recognition of the freedom for employees to join, or not to join, an industrial association. This fundamental freedom is violated by union attempts to impose so-called ‘bargaining agent fees'. Bargaining agent fee clauses in agreements purport to impose an obligation to pay a fee on an employee who is not a member of a union for bargaining services that they did not request. This means non-union workers have to pay for union negotiations at their workplaces even though their concerns may not be represented at all. Effectively, bargaining agent fees act as backdoor compulsory unionism. They are contrary to the principles of freedom of association and should not be included in any form of industrial instrument. To halt the re-emergence of compulsory unionism in the federal sphere, the government introduced the Workplace Relations (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill, which was eventually passed through the Senate with support from the Australian Democrats. The Workplace Relations (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Act 2003 amended the Workplace Relations Act and prohibited compulsory union fees in federal certified agreements. The amendments expressly provided that a bargaining services fee clause in a federal agreement is void. They also provided that a bargaining services fee clause is an ‘objectionable provision' for the purposes of the Workplace Relations Act. This means an agreement should not be certified if it contains a bargaining services fee or, if an agreement has been certified, the bargaining services fee clause may be removed. The legislative change also addressed conduct designed to compel workers to pay such fees. The compulsory union fees act prohibits the making of false or misleading representations about a person's liability to pay a compulsory fee. This was necessary to prevent unions, or employers, from using other methods to create an impression that employees are legally obliged to pay compulsory union fees. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Act 2003 has been successful in addressing bargaining agents fee clauses in federal agreements with bargaining fee provisions removed from 10 certified agreements in January and February of 2004. A further 572 applications made by the Office of the Employment Advocate are currently being considered by the commission. However, as progress is made in the federal jurisdiction, a number of unions have sought to include such clauses in agreements made under state legislation. Recent cases in state jurisdictions have confirmed that bargaining agent fee clauses can be included in state agreements. As state governments appear unwilling to prohibit compulsory bargaining fees in their jurisdictions, it again falls to the Australian government to show leadership on the issue of protecting freedom of association rights. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Extended Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2005 will extend the prohibition on the inclusion of bargaining agents' fee clauses in agreements beyond agreements certified under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to also cover any state employment agreement to which a constitutional corporation is a party. I now turn to the main provisions of the bill. This bill will amend the freedom of association provisions to provide that a bargaining agent fee clause in a state employment agreement to which a constitutional corporation is a party is void. This will apply to agreements entered into on or after the commencement of the amendments made by this bill. The bill will also extend the prohibiits tion on conduct related to the payment of such fees to the widest constitutional extent possible to protect employees from coercion or misleading conduct about their liability to pay such a fee. To achieve these aims, the bill will: - amend the definition of bargaining services to include services provided by an industrial association in relation to a state employment agreement, and - provide that a provision of a state employment agreement to which a constitutional corporation is a party is void to the extent that it requires payment of a bargaining services fee. Australian law recognises that there is an important statutory role for registered organisations and the law confers upon them significant rights and obligations. But the legal standing of unions should not come at the expense of individual employers' and employees' right to freedom of association and protection from coercive or discriminatory conduct. Unions and employer associations are service providers and should rely on the competitiveness and value of the services they offer to attract members. Trade practices legislation prevents ordinary businesses from providing someone with an unrequested service and then demanding payment for it. The same principle should apply to unions and employer associations. The government has a strong, proven commitment to freedom of association and the right of employees to choose whether or not they join a union. Bargaining agent fees are compulsory unionism by stealth and should not be included in any form of industrial instrument. The reintroduction of this bill demonstrates the Australian government's ongoing commitment to upholding employees' freedom of association rights and willingness to act to protect those rights. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr MCClelland) adjourned. NA INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 9 December 2004, on motion by Mr Abbott: That this bill be now read a second time. upon which Ms Gillard moved by way of amendment: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “while not declining to give the bill a second reading, this Parliament condemns the Government for failing to: (1) ensure that private health insurance provides real choice in health care; (2) ensure that private health insurance delivers real value for money; (3) adequately address the health care needs of all older Australians; and (4) provide modelling and data about the impact of the provisions of this bill on the cost of private health insurance for all Australians, thus necessitating the referral of this bill to a Senate committee”.

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: The Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 2004 is another in a series of bills by which the federal government is attempting to change Medicare. It amends the Private Health Insurance Incentives Act 1998 and also the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. There was an election commitment made by the coalition to increase the private health insurance rebate from 30 per cent to 35 per cent for people aged 65 to 69 years and to 40 per cent for people aged 70 years and above. These rebates would be available on both hospital and ancillary cover. The higher rebates will apply to individuals who meet the age threshold and couples or families where one or more of the persons meets the age threshold. The bill makes provision for what should happen in the event of the death of an insurance holder or a family member, or divorce or separation. The problem is that premiums are still rising. It is no good having a system of rebates when the cost of premiums continues to rise. So all those people under 65 are virtually being told to give up their private health insurance because, in spite of the whole pile of policies supporting private health insurance, the 30 per cent rebate and lifetime cover, private health insurance premiums are on the rise. If you happen to be at the lower end of the income scale there is no way you will be able to afford the insurance and pay for all the other necessities of a working family. The Minister for Health and Ageing knows that these costs are increasing. He has not been prepared to admit it in the past and does not really seem to care; it is part of life or death, as the case may be. Although it will help older Australians, if we had a proper Medicare system which was available to all and which was developed in the way it was originally intended, there would be no need to have all these rebates. Health care would be available equally to all those who wished for additional benefits. There could have been the option of paying through private health insurance. Yet we have a government that is propping up the private health system and that is always putting its hand out for more. No matter what it is given, it seems that it has to have more. Wouldn't it be better to put the funds that are being used to subsidise private companies into our public health system to pay for more doctors, more nurses, more health infrastructure, more dialysis machines, more equipment to help cancer patients and more general health surveys? There are millions of different health issues that would benefit if those funds were used to pay for health infrastructure. It is only a matter of time before the advantage gained by raising private health insurance premiums will be overwhelmed by the dollar disadvantage caused by the rise. Back to square one. You hear this all the time from pensioners who have had a small amount attached to their aged pensions: ‘They give with one hand and take away with the other.' So in fact most pensioners and veterans are getting further and further behind in being able to afford the new Australian lifestyle. One of the biggest groups of people coming through my electorate office is of those older Australians who are sitting on waiting lists for elective surgery. It might be elective in the terms of the medical profession but it is not seen as elective for many who wait for cataract surgery or, in severe pain, for hip replacements. Then there are many who are suffering from macular degeneration. It is an insidious disease which affects central vision and can sometimes make it difficult to read, drive or perform other activities requiring fine, detailed vision. It eventually leads to complete loss of sight. The treatment for this disease costs thousands of dollars. It means the difference between an independent, reasonable quality of life in one's own home and dependence on a nursing home or a fullcare existence. Pensioners would go without the basic necessities to keep their independence and life quality, yet there is no assistance for this treatment within the public system and it is not, of course, offered under private insurance. The reality for most elderly Australians who face health emergencies is that they rely on the public health system through the emergency departments of public hospitals. Those are the places where the most up-todate and advanced equipment is available. Despite being covered by private insurance, the elderly end up being turned away from private hospitals because the facilities are not there and the hospitals just cannot deal with the crisis. At the other end of the argument, the more rebates there are for the elderly, the more those people who have the burden of providing the taxes to pay for the rebates will be charged. Judging by the comments that flow through my office, those people are not taking kindly to this and want to know how and when their bills might decrease. So, will more older Australians join private health funds if the rebates are a bit more generous? Has anyone done the figures on this? Of course they have not. Why are we, the taxpayers, giving these rebates when we do not know whether they will help the system work? Who has done the figures, and where are they? I think we deserve to have some answers. The Labor Party is planning to get those answers somehow. It proposes to get some economic modelling undertaken on this legislation through a Senate legislation committee in the hope that there will be some answers before this proposal goes into law. I agree with that. I think it is important we know how much the additional funding will change the equation. I have been trying to find some discussions on this issue and I have found that there have been quite a few journal articles recently that have taken up this topic. For instance, Stephen Duckett, Professor of Health Policy at La Trobe University, had a look at waiting times in hospitals. He tested the hypothesis that increased private activity in the health system is associated with reduced waiting times. As Tasmanians suffer some of the longest waiting times-and Professor Duckett confirms this in his paper-I was interested to see his findings. His conclusions are interesting. He finds that increased private sector activity is associated with increased public sector waiting times. He says his study does have some limitations; but, despite those, it suggests that policy makers should be cautious about pursuing policies based on expanding private access as a strategy for achieving reductions in public sector waiting times, and it correlates the findings of previous overseas studies. So those people on the additional rebate do not hold out any great hope of finding a shorter waiting list for public hospital treatment. Another study, done by Sundararajan, Brown and others, looked at the impact of private health insurance on the utilisation of public hospitals in Australia. The study suggests that the number of patients treated in Victorian public hospitals continues to grow, with the public hospitals also tending to treat patients with more severe diseases. In their discussion those who carried out the study found that it was ‘not uncommon for important changes in the health sector to have unpredictable effects'. The patterns they found in this study were predicted by several analysts. So when looking at the 30 per cent rebate they found that hospitals: ... continue to experience increases in the number of admitted patients as a consequence of many factors including increased efficiency, growing expectations, and demographic changes ... And that there would: ... continue to be considerable unmet need and therefore, if spare capacity emerged, it would quickly be filled by those who had been in waiting (whether on formal lists or not). The paper also quoted from other works which said: ... any shift to care provided under private ance, whether in private or public hospitals, cause a decline in the equity of care provision. The study also pointed out that although there is choice allowed under private health insurance for simple procedures or minor surgery, there is none when it comes to lifethreatening illnesses. The public hospitals take the emergencies. So if we are to see any change in quality of care and waiting lists in the public sector it will not come through beefing up the private sector; it will come through funding the public sector properly. I even looked at an article by Deb Richards in the Medical Observer Weekly entitled, ‘30% and rising-is the rebate really good policy?' She quotes a number of medicos who have been at the sharp end of financing private hospitals. Professor Harper argues that the rebate is a success because when private health insurance numbers went up the growth in public hospital expenditure stabilised. However, then Ms Richards quotes official data that shows growth in public hospital expenditures paused for a year and then continued to climb. Harper concludes that the rebate has saved the public purse much money. Not to be daunted, the reporter asks: If the private sector died, what would be the costs for the public hospitals to pick up the load? Interesting stuff. Professor Harper is quoted as finding that private hospitals perform $4.3 billion worth of procedures, when the costs of the rebate are $2.2 billion. The rebate is a ‘stitch in time'. The debate continues on both sides of the argument throughout the article. The OECD finding concluded that, in all the countries it has studied, private insurance provides greater choice and better access but is inflationary and leads to a two-tier system, which I believe this government is pushing this country towards. So there have been calls to subsidise private hospitals directly, insurrather than through the insurance funds, could which absorb 13 per cent in administrative fees and pay out about 30 per cent on auxiliaries for which there is no public offset. The general conclusion seems to be that the rebate distributes money the wrong way. It is not good health policy if you intend to get as many health services as you can for your dollar but part of those funds is being used to subsidise the activities of the private health insurance companies. All that being said, there is an argument for looking at how the financial models are working-or even whether they are working. The public has a right to know what the answers are, and also the differences between the government's and the opposition's approaches to finding the answers. None of this has been clear during the discussions on private health funds and how they are supposed to affect the overall funding of health care in Australia. We must know whether private health insurance really does provide real choices in health care, whether it delivers real value for money and whether it adequately addresses the health care needs of all older Australians. Therefore, this bill should go to a Senate committee in order to get some of the questions answered. Over the last three years, private health insurance premiums have risen on average by 22 per cent. As several members have said, an easier and better system might be to pay the dollars straight to the private hospitals and save some of the 13 per cent which it costs to run the private health insurance system. We need to look at the billions of dollars going into these rebates, which the government says is achieving something. Many believe that it is not and that we do not get enough for all the money that is being spent on these rebates and on what this bill does. I support the amendment.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: I rise to speak on the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 2004. I am going to say something controversial here-it is a fact that Labor do not understand health policy. There is a myth in the community, probably perpetuated by the Labor spinners themselves, that Labor are the oracle when it comes to health. They believe they have all the answers to all the problems and that only they can have the solutions. I do not believe in their publicity the way they do, and I explain why. The New South Wales health system is proof that Labor has no idea about health policy or the management of hospitals. Waiting lists are blowing out and it can take years for an older person to get a hip replacement or a knee replacement. Doctors are resigning out of frustration with management or because they cannot get the funds to perform elective surgery. At least seven doctors have resigned from the public health system in my area over the past year. Three GPs resigned from the Polyclinic at Nelson Bay because of the shifts which forced them to work a full night and back up and see patients the next day. This sort of rostering went out with ether and masks. According to the Newcastle Herald of 25 September 2004, four gynaecologists resigned from the John Hunter Hospital due to a lack of funding for elective surgery. I am told by one of my constituents that a heart surgeon has also resigned from the public system and for that reason he cannot get his bypass operation. Labor has been in power in New South Wales one year longer than the Howard government has been in power, and the New South Wales health system is in an absolute shambles. While Labor has presided over the crumbling of the New South Wales health system, the Howard government has introduced a range of reforms to the health system to ensure the future of Medicare and the viability of holding private health insurance, including: the Medicare levy surcharge, the universal private health insurance rebate of 30 per cent and lifetime health cover, which encourages people to take out health insurance before they turn 30 and to keep it throughout their lives. The changes this bill will introduce will make private health cover more affordable right at the time it should be most affordable. shall What Labor does not understand is that we need the private sector to be sustainable to ensure that the public sector is not swamped. To date, the shadow health minister has not fully committed to the 30 per cent rebate as it currently stands. The day Labor recognises that families, singles and couples like the rebate and appreciate that it makes it easier to afford private health cover will be the day they come out and state categorically to the Australian people about private health cover: ‘We're keeping it.' Until that day, we have to assume that Labor does not understand that health cover has to be affordable for people to keep it. The rebates-30 per cent for all Australians, 35 per cent for those 65 years and over and 40 per cent for those 70 years and over-help make private health cover more affordable. When Medicare was first formed the percentage of Australians with private health insurance was around 65 per cent. When Labor established Medicare they did so on the assumption that some people would continue their private health insurance while others would need the universal free public system. Neal Blewett, the health minister who introduced the legislation to create Medicare, said at the time: Medicare provides only basic cover and they should look, if they want to do so, to the need private health insurance and its costs. I mentioned before that four visiting gynaecologist-obstetricians resigned from John Hunter Hospital in September. One of them was quoted as saying: When you come along needing a hysterectomy, bleeding half to death every month, and haven't the money to go into a private hospital, me, my next operating list is a month away. I think that if that statement says anything it is that there is a very real need for private health insurance to be affordable if the states cannot provide elective surgery. I also cannot believe that a hysterectomy is elective surgery. Former Labor cabinet minister Graham Richardson knew that keeping people in the private health system would relieve the pressures on the public system. In 1993 Senator Richardson, the then health minister, put the proposal to cabinet that high-income earners without private health insurance be given a higher Medicare surcharge. That was knocked back because-if can you believe the self-interest at play here-the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, did not want to pay it because he was a high-income earner himself. He was a self-declared person who avoided private health insurance. What was Labor's idea for easing the pressure on the public health system? It was Medicare Gold. Medicare Gold was a statement-nothing more. It was a statement of simplistic policy-making that tried to con the voters of Australia. It promised free health care for the over-75s. But they already have free health care in the public system. The other thing that they did not enunciate all that well was that Medicare Gold did not cover ancillaries such as physio, spectacles and dentistry. It did not give the over-75s choice of doctor or choice of health facility. It did not put in place one policy to create doctors, to ease the squeeze on hospitals or for to reduce waiting lists. It was like the Medicare teams idea. Labor would create teams of doctors, out of the many thousands that we do not have surplus at the moment, to visit areas where low rates of bulk-billing are evident. Again, this was a simplistic solution that did not go into depth or even attempt to understand what the work force problems are if you see in the health industry. Interestingly, it was the older voters who raised Labor's Medicare Gold policy with me, saying they did not think it could work. The first question they asked was: what about the ancillaries? What about the physio they would need after the hip replacement, or the new glasses they would need in five years time? Older people know what they need. It was a shame that Labor had never thought to ask older people what they needed. I had one or two of the more selfless in the community ask me: ‘Why do I deserve free health care over a young mother or a sick child?' Some commented that it had shades of Whitlam about it-uncosted, unfunded and unsustainable. The other flaw in Medicare Gold was that there are no public hospitals in either of the two centres which have the greatest proportion of older constituents in my electorate. Currently, my constituents have no access to state public hospital facilities. Under Medicare Gold they would still have had no access to public hospital facilities in their area. I noticed that none of the premiers supported the Labor plan. It was another case of announce first, consult later by the then opposition leader and his health spokeswoman. But the then opposition leader did ask the people. In a public meeting at Raymond Terrace at the beginning of the year, 200 people turned up to tell the former opposition leader what they thought, including one woman who asked what he was going to do to reduce hospital waiting lists. The former opposition leader, of course, did not have the answer then. His answer was to resign. Does the current opposition leader have any idea? I doubt it. Labor is a vacuum of new ideas and a policy black hole in our galaxy. There are two solutions to reducing waiting lists in the public system. The first is build more public hospitals and adequately staff them. In New South Wales, Labor continually closes wards, reduces staff and withdraws the money, particularly in regional areas like mine. The other solution is to provide incentives for people to go into private health insurance, to make that private health insurance system more affordable. As a person gets older, they are more susceptible to health problems and it is precisely as a person needs their health insurance more that we need to encourage them to maintain responsibility for their own health. This bill recognises that at 65 many Australians are not working anymore. That is precisely the time when they seek to make financial adjustments to how they live their lives. Effec- bill. tively, this will mean an increase in their rebate of about $100 to $200 per annum, and that sort of saving for a person on a limited income is not to be sneezed at. The Howard government also recognises that at 70 years of age a person is even more susceptible to health problems and may have further reduced income. Their private health insurance rebate will be increased to 40 per cent. To reduce complication only one person in a partnership needs to be over the eligible age to receive the additional rebate. Voters want choice. They want the option of going to a private hospital, getting their choice of doctor and not waiting for years for elective surgery. Two former Labor health ministers understood the need for a dual health system with a functional private system that would keep people out of the public system. But they are gone now. The current shadow health minister, who has never 100 per cent committed to the private health insurance rebate as it stands, does not understand that those who can pay should be encouraged to do so. For those who cannot pay there is a public systo tem that works and includes a safety net for out of hospital medical expenses, which Labor wanted to abolish. The time has come for politicians to put aside political interests and start to think about the health care of those in our community. If the state system will not build more hospitals, employ more doctors, open more beds or provide greater health services then it is incumbent on members of this House to provide the incentives that will allow our older Australians to contribute to private health insurance to reduce the waiting lists. I ask this question of all members: is it not the goal to provide better health services and to help reduce waiting lists? This bill in part goes a long way towards that. I support this

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: I am particularly pleased to have seconded the second reading amendment to the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 2004 as proposed by the member for Lalor. These amendments condemn the government for not getting it right when it comes to balancing the service provision of the private health insurance sector with the public and private health systems and the health needs of older Australians. In fact, the legislation shows that the government continues to fail the Australian people when it comes to our health system. The Howard government, you recall, has not had a smooth record when it comes to managing its health responsibilities. After the dismal performance in the last term of former health minister Kay Patterson the government put their Mr Fixit, Minister Abbott, in charge. True to his style, we have been given the quick fix-the grab for money and the one-off vote-buying specials. What we have not been given is long-term solutions or health policy reform. As we watch our population age, our medical work force shrink, health care and medication costs escalate and levies and premiums continue to increase and we measure this against health gains for the many billions of dollars spent, everyone in Australia knows that they have a real stake in the government getting it right. But according to the Productivity Commission's draft research report Economic implications of an ageing Australia released in November last year, one-quarter of Australians will be aged 65 years or more by 2044, which is roughly double the present proportion. We know that across health services as a whole expenditure on the over-65s amounts to around four times more per person than that on those under 65, and then rises to between six and nine times more for the oldest groups in our population. As the population ages, health and aged care costs are projected to rise relative to GDP. In the absence of polthe icy responses, the fiscal gaps opened by ageing will sum to around seven percentage points of GDP by 2044, according to the report, with an accumulated value over the 40 years of around $2,200 billion. Actions to improve productivity and achieve more cost-effective service provision, especially in health care, are then of central importance. But on examination, this legislation does not measure up to the Productivity Commission's findings or respond to the economic implications for the health budget. The government's legislation puts into effect their election promise to increase the private health insurance rebate from 30 per cent to 35 per cent for people aged 65 to 69 and up to 40 per cent for people aged 70 years and over. If private insurance was the magic ingredient to delivering good health care, this legislation might work, but only for older Australians with enough money to buy private health insurance. The government believe that that is the way to fix the crisis in health care-get more people into private insurance, into private hospital beds, and therefore reduce the burden on our public health system. They also claim the more people who have private insurance, the lower the premiums will become. But we know that that is not how it has worked in their term of office. Professor Stephen Duckett's study ‘Private care and public waiting', published in the Australian Health Review this month, adds weight to criticisms of the Howard government's $2.5 billion annual subsidy to the private health insurance industry. This is the first Australian study to test if that 30 per cent existing private health insurance rebate is delivering for the Australian people. The study found that the government's private health insurance rebate has actually increased waiting times for treatment in public hospitals. When the Howard government introduced 30 per cent rebate, it argued that it would take the pressure off the public health system. However, this study directly contradicts the government's claim and backs up evidence from Britain and Canada that a higher take-up of private health insurance is associated with longer public waiting lists. In my electorate we know a little bit about that, as it affects us all personally. We are talking about family members and we are talking about neighbours and friends who await surgery at an age when damage can become quite chronic. Professor Duckett found that a one per cent increase in the private sector proportion of funding translates into a 46-day additional wait for public patients. Contrary to claims by the AMA and Tony Abbott, Professor Duckett is not advocating that the rebate be scrapped, but rather argues the point that, if you want to take the pressure off the public sector, you need to invest in the public health sector. Unfortunately, this government's reluctance to scrutinise the impact of private health insurance rebates on the health budget and on the public delivery of health services makes any sensible debate or informed expenditure of taxpayer funds very difficult, if not impossible. This government have tried every way it can think of to get Australians to take out private health insurance, without looking at the cost-benefits to health service delivery. They introduced the Medicare levy surcharge and lifetime health cover-measures that penalised people for failing to health insurance early in their lives. At one stage, in 2000, the take-up of private health insurance increased to a high of 45.7 per cent of our population. But since then private health insurance members seem to have discovered there just was not enough benefit for what they paid, and now the take-up has reduced to 43 per cent and is dropping. Given that over the past five years private health insurance premiums have risen by 33 per cent, about 10 per cent a year-and, dramatically, a 22 per cent increase in premiums over the past three years-it is not surprising that many people have chosen to opt out. Apparently the government thinks they need to do more to get people into private health insurance and have offered the over 65 age group some extra incentives. Research undertaken by ACOSS showed that 84 per cent of people over 65 with an income greater than $100,000 per annum do have private health insurance. But they also found that of those with incomes less than $20,000 per annum only 23 per cent choose private health insurance. The benefit of the legislation before us will flow to those who can already afford to pay for health care costs rather than to those whose health needs are greatest. But that is the government's standard process of policy selection-survival of the wealthiest. In the health domain, one would have hoped policy would be very much linked to health needs. It is unlikely that over-65-year-olds will flock to join private health insurance to gain this additional rebate, particularly given it is only between $2 or $4 a week, and more unlikely if they are joining for the first time and they are aged between 65 and 70. Under the terms of lifetime health cover, they will be paying a lot more than the premium base rate, even with this additional rebate. I quote an elderly couple from my electorate to illustake up private trate this point: Last year we applied to re-join a medical fund ... only to be told the % increase in the fees (2% for every year of age) made the cost prohibitive. We are age pensioners. All my working life we were in a fund ... but this does not count against the yearly ... increases in the fees. Even for those who are already in private health insurance, how long will it be before premium increases erode away that $2 to $4 a week handout? Not long, if precedent can be relied upon. Of course, private health insurance companies are looking for at least a 12 per cent increase in their premiums, and we will know the outcome of their bid very shortly. I quote from another of my constituents, who says: I am concerned about the increase in private health insurance. Despite the Federal government urging the public to take up private health insurance and assuring us that premiums would not rise-after 3 years they have increased beyond affordability. But even if older Australians do join up what will be the long-term consequence of that action? Given that currently over-65s make up 12 per cent of private health insurance membership but constitute 44 per cent of hospital benefits paid out by private health insurers, it may be anticipated that all those members who are under 65 may have to pay even higher premiums to absorb the extra costs to the private health industry. That is not fair and it is not sensible. So what is the real picture for private health insurance for older Australians? Just over a year ago, I surveyed my electorate about private health insurance and Medicare. A staggering 1,071 Novocastrians completed the survey and, at their own cost and inconvenience, sent their responses to me. Of those, 53.4 per cent said they had private health insurance, 68.3 per cent of those with private health insurance reported that their premiums had increased and 50 per cent advised that their fund had increased the excess payable for in-hospital services. Significantly, 65 per cent did not believe that they received value for money from their private health insurer. One older constituent commented: My health fund's attitude is entirely frivolous: for instance I could not claim a refund on my walking stick, but could claim on RUNNERS! An elderly couple also commented: As pensioners, we were unable to continue Private Health Insurance, after being members of a particular insurer in Newcastlefor approximately 20 years. We found that with increased fees, the value of service just wasn't there. Also there is no reward for being a member for so long. When asked about the ‘gap' that people with private health insurance were paying, 84.4 per cent of the Newcastle respondents said that this was continuing to increase. Again, there were strong feelings about this issue, linking back to the question of value for money. As one Adamstown constituent put it: There is no point joining a private health fund if when you pay the bill the gap is so expensive you can't afford it. I am assisting a constituent at the moment who has private health insurance, and her gap for surgery will be in the vicinity of $5,000. That $5,000 is an amazing gap amount for a pensioner already paying private health insurance to pay for surgical attention. Another couple said: We are pensioners and have had severe health problems over the last 12 months. We feel we must be involved in Private health even though we found the treatment and cover falls far short of what is expected. Another constituent reported: Paying $70 for both myself and husband with only $50.70 rebate plus private insurance premiums of $132 per month, we are finding things quite hard. We are very serious about giving up private health care after 40 years. Stephen Duckett's study must be given due consideration by this government, because the reality is that, when emergency health care is needed by older Australians, it is usually provided by the public health care system in a public hospital. That is why there is overwhelming support in my electorate for strengthening Medicare and the public health system. The opposition amendment recommends that this legislation should be tested by a Senate committee against the economic costs and benefits, the health priorities of older Australians and against the benefits of the government increasing their already massive spend on the health insurance rebate. That is the least this parliament could do. Of course, had a Labor government been elected, we would have done a lot more for the health care of all older Australians, a lot more towards reforming the health system in this country and a lot more to find cost-effective ways to manage the health budget. We would have been speaking today on legislation to put into effect Labor's Medicare Gold policy, a policy that was so inspired and creative, so lateral in its extent of operation and so responsive to the real needs of older Australians that it was a serious threat to the Treasment urer and the health minister. You can actually measure the strength of Medicare Gold by the intensity of the attack the government has launched against it. Medicare Gold reeks of reformsomething this government knows very little about-with specific benefits to older Australians and diverse cost benefits for all tralians. Although Medicare Gold targeted the over-75 population, it had potential for flow-on effects right across the health sector. Medicare Gold would have seen the up to 25 per cent spare capacity in private hospitals instantly put to use to respond to the health needs of patients over 75. What country can afford to have expensive hospital beds unused while people wait on growing lists for surgery in public hospitals? Medicare Gold promised that government would meet the costs of health care for over-75s, whether in private or public hospitals, taking out of the equation the ineffective and wasteful cost shifting across the state and federal divide and eliminating the need for people over 75 to pay private health insurance premiums for hospital care. Why would that be feared so much? With government as a monopoly buyer for that age group's health care needs, it could have been anticipated that charges may have reduced as demand increased. Market economics would suggest that private hospital management could lower their charges-and we have seen recently that charges are excessive in private hospitals due to the use of the most expensive procedures and equipment. If Medicare Gold had been introduced, there would have been some certainty of demand, allowing cuts to administration and personnel costs. They would also have had maximum occupancy rates, and, surely with demand levels constantly high, cash flows would have been assured. As the monopoly buyer of a large share of the private hospital market, governthen would have been able to influence costs and charges and quality of service delivery within the private hospital system. I think we all accept that under this government health services will be delivered more and more by the private sector, but we also accept that service delivery has to value add to everything that we want-the best that we Aus- want-in health care. That sounds like the mutual obligation I would like to see operate in the delivery of health services by the private sector. It might also have been anticipated that moving people over 75 into private hospitals' unused beds would have allowed the public hospitals to reduce their waiting lists and eventually ensure that older Australians had access to operations at the time of onset of a medical condition, rather than after considerable debilitation, with the consequential burdens of loss of independence and mobility, and the increased draw on home care and support services. If those over 75 could have those operations in a more timely way, those human and economic costs would be reduced, alleviating the terrible burden on our aged parents and loved ones that we currently experience. That makes an increase in the health insurance rebate look miserable, doesn't it? Well, it is miserable. It is small minded, limited, regressive and just plain poor policy. Medicare Gold would also have reduced the burden on private health insurers by eliminating the cost burden to private health insurers generated by members over 75 years old. By eliminating the customer group that actually costs the most, private health insurers could then have been free to be more creative with their products and services; to build in some incentives for young people to take out insurance and manage their health care at an early stage; and to build in some bonuses for preventative health care. Private health insurers could have become key players in the important work of averting a national health crisis from unchecked diabetes, dementia and the illnesses besetting a rapidly ageing population. Shouldn't the private sector also have a responsibility to help this tion tackle the health priorities as well as gain revenue rewards? It seems to me that private systems can work well to create profit, but they work best when social dividend is also part of their charter and their bottom line of outcomes. My knowledge of the board members of NIB, the largest private health insurer in my electorate of Newcastle, suggests that they really wish to continue the ethos under which NIB began-that is, BHP workers, originally, banding together and contributing financially to gain the best health benefits for their community. But, regrettably, we are not legislating to introduce Medicare Gold. Instead, we are scrutinising the government's legislationlegislation that risks rising private health insurance premiums for everyone, risks further increasing copayments for pharmaceuticals and risks stagnation of waiting lists in public hospitals for Australians of every age group, but particularly for older Australians. With the cost of the rebate already approaching $2.5 billion, this legislation also risks blow-out in the health budget necessitating the government's favourite intervention of raising more hidden taxes, taxes like the Medicare levy and perhaps even an increase in the GST to fund the ever-increasing health needs of an ageing population. That is why the member for Lalor's amendment seeks to have this legislation scrutinised by a Senate committee. Despite the strong need for the government to respond to our ageing population and to manage their health needs efficiently and effectively, and contrary to the Howard government's claim, this legislation is unlikely to encourage people aged 65 to 70 years who do not currently have private health insurance to take it out, as they would still be subject to the maximum lifetime health cover napenalty of 70 per cent. Age pensioners like those quoted above are unlikely to re-enter private health insurance, but those who are currently able to afford it, such as those on incomes over $100,000, will receive a shortterm gain-and all for a gain by the Howard government of three more years in power. Contrary to the government's claim that private health insurance reform is all about choice, efficiency and delivering better value for money, there is nothing in this bill to ensure that any of these objectives are met. The one certainty Australian families can expect is yet another substantial increase in private health insurance premiums, and that will occur very soon.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: Rankin) (9.55 a.m.)The Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 2004 increases the rebate for private health insurance from 30 to 35 per cent for people aged 65 to 69 and to 40 per cent for those aged over 70. Labor is not opposing this legislation. We do want a Senate inquiry to assess its impacts, because the claims that the government has made about a this policy are mere assertion, and there is certainly value in testing those assertions. There is already rising evidence to suggest that the assertions that the government has made are not soundly based. The reality is that these increases in the private health insurance rebate are more likely to benefit those on higher incomes because the private health insurance rebate is accessed by those on higher incomes to a much greater extent than it is by those on lower incomes. One piece of evidence has been gathered by ACOSS, the Australian Council of Social Service, which has published survey data indicating that 84 per cent of those aged over 65 who have incomes over $100,000 are covered by the private health insurance rebate, but only 23 per cent of people with an income below $20,000 are covered by the private health insurance rebate. Whether or not those figures are absolutely accurate, the point remains that there is at least some evidence which coincides with intuitive reasoning that the private health insurance rebate is accessed and used more by older Australians on higher incomes than by those on lower incomes and therefore that the increase in the rebate to 35 cent for one category of older Australians and 40 per cent for another is going to benefit those on higher incomes much more than those on lower incomes. We should not be surprised about that. ter all, this is a Liberal-National Party govment. ernment, and it is its philosophic preference to reward those who are up the income scale and not to reward those who strive hard all their lives but end up without large incomes. Indeed, we saw that with the tax policy released by the coalition, where the forgotten people, those below $52,000 a year, got not one cent of income tax reduction, but those above $52,000 a year got a fairly reasonable income tax cut. So this legislation and the philosophy behind it really mirror the tax legislation that was announced in the budget and passed through this parliament late last year-that is, a system that benefits those on higher incomes more than those on lower incomes. I do not mind the idea of benefiting people on higher incomes-I do not think we should be into class envy-but why do the people on lower incomes always miss out under this government? Indeed, the legislation will reward those who can afford to purchase private health insurance, and of course it offers absolutely nothing to those who cannot afford to purchase it. As I say, they are overwhelmingly people over 65 who are just not in a situation to be able to buy private health insurance. One of the great concerns is how long any benefit from this increase in the private health insurance rebate will last. Sadly, it is likely to be not very long at all. Based on past premium increases, it is quite likely that, within a period of one to two years, premium increases will gobble up any benefits to those who take out private health insurance. I say that because over the past three years private health insurance premiums have risen by a staggering 22 per cent and over the past five per years they have risen by around 33 per cent. At those rates, any benefit that did flow to holders of private health insurance would be gone within two years as the private health insurance industry appropriated the financial Afgains that have been offered by the governTo those who receive the private health insurance rebate, I say, ‘Be happy for a short period of time, until the health minister does what he has always done as health minister: rubber-stamp premium increases.' On that form, we will see those premium increases coming forward pretty quickly, wiping out the benefits within two years. It reminds me of a statement about our health system that the Prime Minister made fairly recently. It has been pretty clear throughout his performance over the last 25 to 30 years that he wants to return to the preWhitlam health system. That is not my assertion; it is what the Prime Minister has said. In 2003, on A Current Affair, he said to Ray Martin that he liked the system that was in place before the Whitlam Labor government was elected. He said that the election of the Labor government destroyed a system that he thought was pretty good. Without going into ancient history, let us just discuss some of the characteristics of the system that was in place before 1972. One of the defining characteristics was the large number of people who were not covered by health insurance at all. You would think that in an advanced country a fundamental obligation of any government is to ensure quality health care for all its citizens, yet large numbers Australians had no private health insurance at all because they could not afford it. Often hospitals were benevolent and did not kick them out, but people who had no insurance and no capacity to pay did not have reasonable access to hospital and tended to be forced to the back of the queue. To my mind, that is not the definition of a decent health care system that provides quality health care for all. When the Prime Minister was Treasurer in the Fraser government, they systematically dismantled Medibank. The Fraser government had seven different health systems in seven years. By the end of that period, upon the election of the Hawke government, two million Australians had no health insurance. With the introduction of Medicare, a revamped version of Medibank, all Australians were covered in one decisive initiative: they had their health costs insured through Medicare. That was a great reform. Sadly this government gives lip service to the maintenance of Medicare, when in fact the overwhelming desire of the Prime Minister is to dismantle Medicare by stealth and to favour the private system. This legislation is further evidence of that. Before government ministers suggest that I am saying we should abolish the private health insurance rebate, I am not. The government has a mandate for this legislation, and that is why Labor will allow it to pass. But I note that there has been a lot of criticism of Medicare Gold by the Treasurer. He says that the problem with Medicare Gold is that we have this massive challenge-the ageing of the population-and that to provide free health cover for those over the age of 75 is unaffordable. Isn't it strange that when Labor wanted to do it the Treasurer and the Prime Minister said that it was irresponsible to provide older Australians with extra health benefits that would cost the of budget a lot, but when the coalition does it it is entirely affordable. That seems to be the argument. I think we need to be careful about committing to expenditures that will only compound dramatically over the next 40 years with the ageing of the population. I think some of the criticism of Medicare Gold is valid, and Labor is now looking at a Medicare Gold type of policy. One of the strongest features of a Medicare Gold type of policy is that it would remove the cost shifting that goes on between the Commonwealth and the states. I think that is a very great strength of a Medicare Gold type of policy. But the Treasurer cannot have it both ways. He cannot say on the one hand that it is irresponsible to load up the budget with increased costs for the health of older Australians via Medicare Gold but that it is all right to load up the budget with increased health costs from lifting the private health insurance rebate to 35 per cent and 40 per cent. I have done some calculations on this. Based on the budget forecasts, the private health insurance rebate increase for older Australians is likely to cost in the order of $150 million in 2007-08, on current prices. But, when you add that to a number of other initiatives that this government has taken over the last few years, it certainly is arguable that the government itself is not responding properly to the ageing of the population, because other measures have also been taken that will compound dramatically over time as the number of older Australians increases. To give some perspective on that, the population projections conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics suggest that in 40 years time there will be four million more Australians over the age of 65 but 200,000 fewer children. There will be only one million more Australians aged 15 to 55 and another million aged 55 to 65. What does that mean? It means a massive ageing of the population-four million more Australians over the age of 65. The whole Intergenerational Report was prepared because Treasury was concerned about the ageing of the population and, in particular, the health costs of the ageing population to the budget. Treasury concentrated on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, but that is but one component of compounding costs associated with the ageing of the population. There are other components as a result of the decisions taken by this government over the last five years. We have already identified the increase in the private health insurance rebate. What about the seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors card? That is likely to cost another $70 million in 2007-08. The reduction in tax-that is, the lifting of the effective free threshold for those over the age of 65is expected to cost around $300 million in 2007-08. Also, an exemption of superannuation from social security means tests for those over 55 is likely to be in the order of $90 million, and a telephone allowance for seniors healthcare card holders is rather small at $25 million. I also need to add in here that the superannuation surcharge reduction is expected to cost in the order of $385 million in 2007-08. If you add all of those up you get more than $1 billion. In some respects $1 billion may not seem to be a massive amount of money, but it is $1 billion for those who are senior citizens in this country in 2007-08. If you believe the Intergenerational Report, the ABS population projections, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister that there is a massive problem of the ageing of the population, then these costs will compound dramatically over the next 40 years. It is passing strange that the Treasurer criticises Medicare Gold on the basis that it is unaffordable but when the government implements measures that load up costs for older Australians where those costs will compound dramatically over 40 years, it seems to be saying that it is entirely affordable. A light needs to be shone on the commitment by the government to such expenditures. I know government ministers would like to say that I am therefore opposing all these measures. I am not opposing these measures; I am not suggesting that they be reversed. It is quite hypocritical of this government to criticise any Labor policy to improve the health and well-being of older Australians as being unaffordable, but, when it does it-and it is usually directed towards the private system-then apparently that is completely affordable. The reality of these increases is that the government wants to keep the private health insurance industry happy, because the tax- private health insurance industry and its spokespeople are great supporters of the Howard government. That is the political equation. But let us go beyond the political equation and look at some of the economic dimensions of these sorts of policies. The legislation we are debating here today contains costs which are part of a $66 billion spending spree undertaken by this government since the last budget and through the election campaign to secure its re-election. Over four years $66 billion has been committed by this government, not necessarily to improve the welfare of Australians and certainly not to invest in the nation's future because, of that $66 billion, as little as $5 billion can be identified as genuine investment in the nation's future, the remainder being effectively consumption spending. Late last year I expressed concerns in the address-in reply to the Governor General's speech on 17 November about the practice of the government of engaging in a consumption spending spree when Australian consumer spending was already very high. I know it is a little unusual to quote yourself in a speech but I thought I would draw some parallels between this, what I said late last year, and the Statement on Monetary Policy released two days ago by the Reserve Bank. I said, in part: Australia's consumption boom has been fuelling domestic inflation. A four per cent increase prices of non-tradables over the last 12 months has been disguised by a reduction in the Australian dollar value of tradables, keeping the overall inflation rate within the Reserve Bank's target range. The IMF, in its report last week, identified these inflationary pressures and warned that the dampening effect of inflation from tradable goods may be eroding owing to the recent easing of the Australian dollar. I went on to say: Employment figures released on 11 November indicate a tight job market, pointing to another possible source of pressure-wage inflation fuelling domestic price inflation-and, despite the slowing of the housing market, consumer confidence seems to be going from strength to strength. I warned: There is a whiff of the late 1980s about the present consumption boom. Consumers are behaving as if nothing will stop them from continuing on their merry spending way. If consumers do pull back in the new year, in response to falling housing prices, there will be an economic slowdown. If they do not, as seems more likely at present, the Reserve Bank will be forced to hike interest rates, causing a sharper slowdown. I asked: Where is the Howard government in all this? I said: ... the government is spending on consumption, fuelling the consumption flames. To avert damaging interest rate rises, the federal government should have been reining in Commonwealth spending instead of engaging in this consumption spending spree. The longer it waits before displaying some fiscal responsibility, the harder the landing will be. The Reserve Bank Statement on Monetary Policy, released two days ago, says this, in part: Most economic data in Australia have continued to suggest strong conditions recently. The monetary policy talks about the performance of the labour market and consumer in confidence being close to record levels. It states: ... the range of other available information suggests that the economy was in a strong condition through last year and is likely to have maintained a good pace of growth entering 2005. It talks of capacity constraints becoming more important and of the disappointing performance of our exports to date, which I did mention in my speech last year. It states: For the past couple of years, underlying inflation has been held down by the lagged effects of the exchange rate appreciation that took place during 2002 and 2003, but the maximum impact from that source has now passed. Hence it is likely that underlying inflation has now reached its low point and that it will start rising during 2005. Domestically-sourced inflation has been running faster over the past couple of years ... And so it goes on. I have to say that there are pretty striking similarities between what I said last year and what the Reserve Bank said two days ago, in trying to warn of the consequences of the spending spree that this government has engaged in. Yet what did the Treasurer say at the end of last year? On the last day of parliament he said: I hope ... that we will have a good retailing season this Christmas. So we have the Treasurer saying: ‘Spend away! Go for your life!' And why wouldn't the Treasurer be saying that, because the government is going for its life with a $66 billion spending spree. There is a consumption boom in this country and now the Reserve Bank is finally warning that, as a consequence of it, it may have to raise interest rates because the government will not act. Enough of the government's hypocrisy on health policy; enough of the government's hypocrisy on economic policy. The government is asleep at the wheel. It should wake up and start managing this economy. Otherwise, we will be in for a hard landing.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: In summing up the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 2004 and closing the second reading debate, I wish to thank all members who have participated. As you would expect on a topic such as health, there have been some strong views expressed and some good arguments put. I thank members for their interest in this area. This bill demonstrates the Howard government's commitment to a strong private sector in health as an essential complement to a strong public sector in health. We cannot have a strong and viable Medicare system without a strong and viable private health care sector as well. As members should be aware, more than 50 per cent of all surgery today takes place in the private hospital system. If the private hospital system were, for whatever reason, unable to continue, we would immediately have far greater problems in our public hospital system than we currently have. Without a strong private sector we cannot have a strong public sector, and we cannot have a strong private sector without a strong and viable system of private health insurance. The private sector in health rests upon private health insurance, and that is why this government has always been determined to try to ensure the continuing strength of the private health insurance industry. The government has considerable achievements to its credit. Back in the midto late-nineties private health insurance coverage had dropped to about 30 per cent of the population. Today, thanks to Lifetime Health Cover and the private health insurance rebate, private health insurance coverage is about 43 per cent of the population. Some nine million Australians have private health insurance cover, including one million Australians with incomes of less than $20,000 a year. Most of those low-income Australians with private health insurance are older people, and most of those older people have had their private health insurance for many years. Their private health insurance predates Lifetime Health Cover and it predates the private health insurance rebate. They have paid and paid for their private health insurance cover and, in so doing, they have helped to bear the burden of the health costs of all Australians over the years. The government believes it is right and proper that those people should have a modest but significant additional incentive to maintain their private health insurance cover. The last thing we would want is for older people, at precisely the time in their lives when they are most likely to need additional medical attention, to drop their private health insurance cover because they are finding the financial burden prohibitive. This bill will provide, thanks to the 35 per cent and 40 per cent private health insurance measures for people over 65 and over 70, a benefit of $100 or $200, on average, to these people. Perhaps it will lead to some modest increases in private health insurance cover for older people, but certainly it should help to ensure that older people do not drop out of their private health insurance cover. I want to thank members opposite for the indication that the ALP will not oppose this legislation. I think that is an indication that members opposite have learnt something from recent political history. I think members opposite have learnt that people want to be able to have that little bit of additional control over their lives that private health insurance brings. There are still some confusing signs coming from members opposite; there are still some signs of ideological confusion from members opposite. Are they or are they not committed to the Medicare Gold policy? Will they or will they not really embrace the private health sector as a positive good, rather than as a necessary evil? I think that shades of the former Leader of the Opposition still inhabit members opposite. I think the ghost of Mark Latham still haunts this debate. As you will remember, the former member for Werriwa did say of the private health insurance rebate that it was the ‘maddest piece of public policy' ever to come out of this parliament. But members opposite are starting to move on, and that is to their credit. I am pleased that they are getting over it. Nevertheless, I think there is still some way to go. One of the issues that has arisen since this policy was announced in consultation with the private health insurance sector is what might happen to people who are not over 65 but who are currently covered by a policy which includes someone who is over 65 and therefore attracts the higher rebate. I want to make it very clear that the government's intention is that nobody should be kicked off their cover as a result of this legislation. It is possible that these new arrangements will need finetuning after practical experience of their operation. The government will monitor the implementation of the seniors' rebate, review its operation after the first six to 12 months and, if necessary, make any legislative finetuning that is desirable. This is an important piece of legislation. It will significantly strengthen the private health sector in this country. I am pleased that it is not going to be opposed by the opposition. I commend it to the House, and I think that older Australians can be confident that their future, their health security, is in good hands with the Howard government.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Lalor has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. Question agreed to. Original question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA AMENDMENT (ADJUSTMENT OF CERTAIN FTB CHILD RATES) BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 18 November 2004, on motion by Ms Ley: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Title: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION
text: I rise to speak on the bill on behalf of my colleague the member for Sydney, who is currently on maternity leave, and I do so with great pleasure. It is interesting that the bill that I will be speaking on is the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004, obviously something of interest to all of those who have families. At the outset I can indicate that Labor do support the passage of this bill, but we do note that this bill has only been necessary to correct the flaws in the indexation provisions of the Family Assistance Act 1999 that arose as a result of changes made under the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families-Increased Payments) Bill 2004, which introduced the $600 per child family tax benefit supplement. Labor said from the start that the government had either made a major blunder or sneakily changed the formula for calculating fortnightly family tax benefit A payments so that it could recover or claw back the value of the per child supplement over time. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, and her former colleague Larry Anthony responded by claiming that the government was fully committed to maintaining the real value of the per child supplement over time. But neither Senator Patterson nor Mr Anthony ever addressed Labor's key charge that the government had deceived families by fiddling with the formula for the fortnightly FTBA payments when it introduced the per child supplement in the 2004 budget. After two months of insisting that there was no problem, Senator Patterson belatedly conceded in August last year that she and Mr Anthony had botched the original legislation and that it needed to be changed yet again. So here we are. Senator Patterson then of course broke her promise to fix the problem before the federal election. The government finally introduced this bill into the House on 18 November, six months after it created the mess in the budget legislation. Debate on the bill was then delayed until this session, well after Senator Patterson's promise to correct the problem once and for all. The bill itself, as members of the House might be able to tell, even from that brief history of it, is a technical bill. It seeks adjust the indexation provisions of the Family Assistance Act 1999 so that the detrimental impact of changes made by the government as part of its 2004 More help for Families legislation is reversed. The bill amends the family tax benefit adjustment provisions in schedule 4 of the Family Assistance Act 1999 that apply in relation to the family tax benefit A under-13 and age 13-15 child rates. Under the new arrangements provided for in the bill if the FTBA under 13 child rate, as indexed by the consumer price index, is less than the amount worked out using the formula of the combined pensioner rate times 16.6 per cent-where the combined pensioner rate refers to combined pensioner couple-then the FTBA under-13 rate is increased to the amount determined under the formula. The position is the same for the family tax benefit A age 13-15 child rate, except that the multiplier is 21.6 per cent. Collectively these tests are more simply known as the safety net benchmark provisions. These provisions had been introduced by previous Labor governments to ensure adequacy of fortnightly payments to Australian families. The arrangements provided for in this bill are the same as those which applied to FTB payments prior to the passage of the budget legislation last year. The bill does not make any changes to the future indexation arrangements for the supplementary FTB payment, which will continue to be adjusted by the CPI. Since the per child supplement was introduced, Labor has pointed out that the effect of other changes made in that same legislation was that the supplementary payment would be fully recovered or clawed back by the government over time. This was because changes in the budget legislation to the formula for calculating fortnightly FTBA payments compromised the existing safety net benchmark and the value of the per child to supplement would be eroded within a fiveto seven-year period. This position was supported by the Australian Council of Social Service, which noted in its press release on 21 June 2004: ... the new indexation rules will see Family Tax Benefit rise more slowly than it would have under current rules. The value of the $600 increase be washed away The safety net benchmarks which were introduced by Labor and carried over in the Family Assistance Act 1999 have not influenced FTB payments recently because those payments have been well above the benchmarks since the FTB system was introduced. However, this will change in the future when the benchmarks catch up with FTB fortnightly payments. The effect will be that the fortnightly FTBA payments will then start to increase at a lower rate than would have been the case prior to the changes to the formula that were made in last year's budget legislation. Labor argued that, after five to seven years, the value of the foregone increase in FTBA payments would have been greater than the value of the supplementary payment to families. So the government would have clawed back the value of the supplementary payment by reducing the normal fortnightly payments. As I have said, despite denials at the time from Senator Patterson and former junior minister Larry Anthony, the changes made when the supplementary payment was introduced did alter the formulas used to calculate the benchmarks. Under sections 6 and 7 of schedule 1 of the budget legislation, while 16.6 per cent or 21.6 per cent of the annualised combined partnered pension rate was still calculated, the result of that calculation was reduced by the FTB supplement. These new formulas therefore resulted in lower benchmarks. While the lower benchmarks would still increase in line with movements in male total average weekly earnings, they would take longer to rise to match the CPI indexed FTBA rate. It would only be at that time that the benchmarks started to influence the FTBA rate. So the new benchmarks, which are lower than before because the supplementary payment is deducted, would eventuwill ally produce lower rates of FTBA than the original benchmarks. Hence Labor's claim, supported by ACOSS, that the effective value of the $600 supplement would be eroded over time by this detrimental change to the formula for calculating fortnightly FTBA payments. Obviously Australian families were going to miss out.
