My real concern is that, if the federal government were truly committed to delivering something for the people of Australia through a great nation-building scheme like the Snowy Mountains scheme, why has it made the funding conditional? Why will the government hold back funding indefinitely until it gets its whims on a number of issues dealt with? To me this does not sound like a government that is committed to nationbuilding. If you want to talk about great schemes like the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme, it would have been a disgrace had the government of the day made that conditional, as it is a disgrace today to have the funding in a document like AusLink made conditional upon a government's personal ideology. Instead of delivering infrastructure, getting on with the job and putting some time frames in place, we are seeing something very far from that. One of things that concerned me during the election campaign was the curious sums in the funding discussed by government members and ministers when they went from electorate to electorate. There is no question about the amount of money contained in AusLink because it is all in the budget papers and there for everyone to see. Some $627 million will be committed over the next five years to five projects with the Brisbane urban connectors and the corridor. But by the is government's own calculations, for the life of that document, conservatively, they are short $2.5 billion. So they have put $627 million forward, but they have come up short by at least $2.5 billion. It is pretty easy looking at the projects, doing the sums and dividing the money over five years, that they cannot deliver all of them. That is the simple mathematics of this. Curiously, what government members and the minister did, very deceptively I have to say, was to travel from electorate to electorate and reannounce that same bucket of money-$627 million for the entire five years for all of the projects. They said: ‘We have actually got the money on the table. The state just has to take the money. The state needs to grab the bucket, take the money and deliver the projects.' But they cannot do that with the same bucket of money for all five projects. I know it may be a bit complicated for government members to understand this, but it is simple mathematics. You do not have enough money and it is not funded-not only over the next five years but also in the forward estimates. By my calculations of the forward estimates through to 2009, there is no funding either now or in those budgets. It means that either one out of the five projects will be delivered in its entirety or a range of projects will be fiddled with. This is a case of the government fiddling while Rome is burning. It will be many years down the track before we (a) see the money and (b) actually get the roads that are promised to us in this AusLink program. The Brisbane urban corridor connectors of the five projects are particularly important. They are the duplication of the Gateway Bridge, the Brisbane urban corridor through Mount Gravatt, the Ipswich motorway upgrade, the Ipswich motorwayLogan motorway interchange, and traffic management programs through the Brisbane urban corridor. But, as I said, this view that the money is on the table is far from correct, because you cannot spend the same money in five different places. It is as simple as that. It will be no surprise to people that within the AusLink document a little bit of trickery takes place in terms of funding. The government talks about a future commitment and maintenance of funding, but it does not tell you that it has actually capped the funding. In the forward estimates and future budgets, the dollars will continue to decline in real terms in relation to the CPI. Again, this is federal government walking away from its responsibility to the nation for roads and infrastructure. We in the Labor Party do not just talk about this. We actually want to see some change. We want to see some money spent. We want to see a commitment to a range of projects around the country. Just prior to the last election, as part of our commitment to this nation, we put forward a number of policies, including $700 million for the full upgrade of the Ipswich motorway, $25 million for the construction of a grade separated rail overpass at Acacia Ridge, a commitment to upgrade the inner sections at Kessels and Main roads, and a range of other projects in Queensland. We also made commitments in a number of other states. We believe that it was in the best interests of all people living in those electorates, regardless of whether they were Labor or Liberal, because the flow-on effects would benefit everybody, not just a few people. There have been a number of years of neglect and there is certainly no money in budgets to reflect the nation's need for some serious infrastructure: some roads, some rails and some cycling paths-things that are important to a range of communities. Instead, what we have seen is a classic case of porkbarrelling from The Nationals, something that they are proud of and something they even talk about. (Time expired) Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (1.48 p.m.)-It gives me great pleasure to rise in the House in this debate on the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004. Reading the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and listening to government members opposite, one would be forgiven for believing that the national land transport the plan was the grand product of the visionary minds of the Liberal-National parties. Historically, that is not the case. The HawkeKeating Labor government actively implemented a strategic and integrated land transport plan when it was in office. That was part of a massive economic contribution that Labor in government made to the current economic prosperity that Australians enjoy. Indeed, it was Labor in government that set the growth benchmark of four per cent per annum for the four years before it left office. If you listen to honourable members opposite-the Treasurer and the Prime Ministeryou would think that four per cent growth was something new. Sorry, but Labor left the Liberal Party and the National Party a growth rate in Australia of four per cent in the four years before it left office. It was Labor in government that broke the back of double digit Liberal inflationreducing it to under two per cent and laying the basis for the low interest rate regime that we currently enjoy. It was Labor that brought unemployment below the historical 10 per cent levels that prevailed when John Howard had stewardship of the treasury bench, it was Labor that transformed this country's industrial structure to the innovative and productive economy that we see today and it was Labor in office that provided a proper infrastructure planning framework for road, rail, sea and air transport in this country. My involvement in land transport issues and my pursuit of a strategic and integrated approach to funding of essential infrastructure in this area goes back to before I entered this parliament in 1993. I was a member of a Geelong community lobby group in the early 1990s that successfully lobbied the then Labor government to route the national standard gauge through Geelong, in my electorate. I have successfully lobbied state and federal governments for funding to integrate road and rail modes and provide links to the port of Geelong. I have actively promoted Avalon airport as a transport hub and an airfreight and passenger centre, with plans to integrate the significant transport assets of the Geelong region, namely Avalon airport, the port of Geelong, the national standard gauge line, the Princes Highway and the major state road networks. Since I was elected in 1993 to the seat of Corio, I have also been an active part of a successful lobbying effort to construct a third lane on the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne. I modestly say I played a not too insignificant role in lobbying within my party's ranks for the Geelong bypass funding. This secured a bipartisan commitment at the federal level to funding this strategic piece of infrastructure in the Geelong region. I mention these involvements because this is an area close to my heart. It is important to my electorate of Corio and the Geelong community and it is central to my shadow ministerial portfolio responsibilities in agriculture and fisheries. That is why I was absolutely dismayed today when I read the headline in the Geelong Advertiser ‘Ring road funds spat'. The article reported that the AusLink funding for key Victorian road projects, including the Geelong ring road, was not going anywhere unless Melbourne's Scoresby bypass became a freeway. That was the attitude of the federal government. I quote from that article: A spokesman for Federal Transport Minister John Anderson returned firebecause of this spatand said the State Government had known since May 2004 that Scoresby would have to be a freeway to free up AusLink money. “They're lying through their teeth, I'm sorry but there's no other word for it,” Mr Anderson's spokesman Paul Chamberlin said. Here we have the minister's spokesperson in the Geelong Advertiser today linking the provision of AusLink funding to the Scoresby project in Melbourne. We know how quickly the minister abandoned that particular position because today he said that he was going to quarantine the Scoresby funding and let the other projects proceed. This is a very important project to the Geelong region. Mr MCArthur-You're against it! Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-I note the presence in the House today of the honourable member for Corangamite who rode the wave of this funding announcement back into the seat of Corangamite and made great play of the announcement. What the honourable member for Corangamite did not do and what the Treasurer did not do at the time was say to the Geelong people that this funding was contingent on the Scoresby being a freeway. Here is the headline of the arrogant Treasurer of this country and the honourable member for Corangamite who is in this chamber today. Mr Fitzgibbon-It's outrageous! Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-Yes. Government finally hears our roar on the ring road push. Nowhere in that article does it say that you are tying the AusLink funding to the Scoresby project. Indeed, on 7 June our arrogant Treasurer issued a press release in which he says a $186 million contribution to the building of the Geelong bypass will be undertaken as part of the AusLink funding. Nowhere in that press release do I see this matter tied to any other project in Victoria. Then I went to the Hon. John Anderson's press release of 9 December that told the people of Geelong how good the government was about funding the Geelong bypass. Nowhere in that press release, honourable member for Corangamite, did I see any reference at all by the arrogant Deputy Prime Minister to tying the AusLink funding for the Geelong bypass to the Scoresby project. Of course once a little bit of pressure comes in they cave in like a deck of cards. The former Prime Minister of this country, Paul Keating, infamously said that John Howard was like a shiver waiting for a spine to go up it; we on this side of the House regard the Treasurer in that vein now. He will not take the Prime Minister on and wrest the prime ministership from John Howard. He is going to sit there, quite meekly, and he is going to cop it. He is going to sook his way into the prime ministership. Let me tell you: you will not get any quarter from us down in the Corio electorate and the Geelong region when you attempt to deceive the Geelong people about tying in the AusLink funding for an essential national project based on your political obsessions and prejudices. You have tried to do it with the code of conduct that you seek to impose on state governments all around the country and now you want to play the same game on a major national piece of infrastructure expenditure. You are a bunch of weak-kneed nellies because yesterday John Anderson's hot gun in his office was saying the Victorian government was lying through its teeth, it always knew the funding for the other AusLink projects was contingent on Scoresby, and here is the backflip. Here is the spineless backflip by the Deputy Prime Minister. I want the member for Corangamite and the Deputy Prime Minister to tell us in the Geelong region the answer to this question: are you going to front up with the $186 million to complete the bypass or are you not? We want to know in the Geelong region because we do not want any more of these shenanigans. We want proper policy. Mr Fitzgibbon-Here he is now! Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-Here is the man who is absolutely and intractably upset with the Victorian government on this matter of the Scoresby funding. Deputy Prime Minister, you are also a shiver waiting for a spine to go up it, me old china. Here is his adviser saying, ‘The Victorians knew all along that the funding for the Geelong bypass was contingent on the Scoresby,' and today the Deputy Prime Minister says, ‘I'm going to quarantine Scoresby and all the other projects will proceed.' By Jove they will proceed, because they are in the national interest and even you recognised that when you jumped on the bandwagon after the state Labor government made a commitment a year ahead of you to this particular project. You stand up in this place, and the honourable member does as well

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION
text: Order! I remind the member for Corio to refer to members by the name of their seat or their title. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-Yes, I will. The honourable member for Corangamite claims credit for the funding for the third lane. The Deputy Prime Minister does that too. Steve Bracks, the Premier of Victoria, and the current Leader of the Opposition made that commitment long before you ever entered the ring. We are quite happy for you to play catch-up on this particular project because we need the $186 million. But do not go running around like a bunch of spineless

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION
text: Order! It being 2.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. NA Ms Cornelia Rau

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the family of Cornelia Rau has called for a full, independent judicial inquiry into their sister's case, saying that only a public inquiry will suffice? Why doesn't the Prime Minister do what the family wants?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am aware of those remarks. I am also aware of some other remarks made by the family, and I respect their feelings. This is a difficult case but the Leader of the Opposition must know that in a situation like this the government has to take a balanced approach and not automatically do what is requested of it by an individual family. The person who has been appointed has great experience, and he is widely respected on both sides of the House. I would have thought that, in a matter that involved an investigation into how somebody was taken into detention who it is claimed should not have been in detention, somebody with the police experience of Mick Palmer was quintessentially the right person to do the inquiry. Middle East: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the government's reaction to the successful talks held overnight between Israel and the Palestinians?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Deakin for his question. I know he was an observer at the Palestinian election. He did an excellent job, and we look forward to reading his report. The elections there were very positive. Australia welcomes the summit meeting that took place yesterday in Sharm El Sheikh, in Egypt, between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and the new President of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas. We are encouraged by the announcement out of this summit of a cessation of violence, which of course is a fundamental prerequisite for peace. After four years of violent conflict and with some 4,700 people having been killed by both sides during the intifada, this clearly is a very important step forward. We would urge both sides to do what they can to try to take advantage of this agreement and maintain the momentum for peace. These are the best prospects we have seen for quite some time for a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. The two-state solution, which must be the solution to the dispute between the Israelis and the Palestinians, is now within reach. The road map to peace in the Middle East, as the peace process is called, is really the only path forward, and it is important that it be embraced by all. We continue to provide our practical support as best we can to the Palestinian people through our aid program. This financial year we budgeted for $12 million worth of aid for the Palestinian people, and we urge the Palestinians to do everything they can within their power to stop extremists committing acts of violence. We also urge the Israelis to fulfil their part of the road map. It is not a question of being rosy-eyed about this. We have to think clearly about it and understand the risks and dangers. This encouraging development has followed on from what I think were enormously important elections within the Palestinian territories. The government is enormously encouraged that we are increasingly seeing democracy in places where democracy was, at best, half-hearted. We have seen elections in the Palestinian territories. In the Ukraine there was finally a free and democratic election. In Afghanistan, there were democratic elections, which so many people said would not be possible. Above all, in Iraq, and despite the intimidation, we have seen a free election with a very substantial turnout. It is an enormous moment for the international community to see democracy spreading. The international community can rest assured that Australia will always be there to support it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, why are Australian Defence Force personnel having to put their lives on the line to defend Australian Embassy building in Baghdad, a building which since the removal of Australian diplomats to Camp Victory has become nothing more than a vacant piece of real estate? Prime Minister, rather than have ADF personnel travel on an extraordinarily dangerous road, why not locate them with the diplomatic personnel they are protecting?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The reason is that the advice we have received from the Chief of the Defence Force is that under current circumstances the best option was for the security detachment to remain where it is. I want to assure the House that on these matters I will take the advice of General Cosgrove. Economy: Consumer Confidence

Speaker: Mr SOMLYAY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline for the House data released today on consumer confidence? What are the factors underpinning this result?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Fairfax for his question. Today Westpac released consumer sentiment for February which, although it showed a slight decline-falling by 0.6 per cent-is still the third highest level of consumer confidence in the 30-year history of the survey since the survey began in 1974. In fact, over the last year consumer sentiment has risen 3½ per cent to be 22 per cent above the long term average, which is quite extraordinary. Why are Australian consumers recording such high levels of sentiment at the moment? Labour market conditions are the best they have been for 30 years, with unemployment down to 5.1 per cent. Household disposable income has been growing around nine per Iraq cent per annum, driven by strong employment and solid real wages growth. I do want to make this point: it is the government's view that we would like to see real wage the increases, unlike Labor, which championed the cause of real wage decline during the 1980s, but we know that real wage increases can only be based on productivity. In addition, household wealth has grown quite significantly over the last two years. As people start filing their tax returns, those eligible families that are on family tax benefit part A will also be receiving, again, a $600 lump sum, notwithstanding the fact that Labor's new so-called economic spokesman maintains the money does not exist. I was doing a radio interview last week and the commentator pointed out to me that, with four children, he got $2,400 last year. I asked him what he did with it. He said he bought a greyhound and he called it ‘Lump Sum'. The money was not provided so that you could buy greyhounds but it was the first time. I ever heard you could buy a greyhound without real money-a lot of people have lost real money on greyhounds. Families will be eligible for a second payment once they lodge their income tax return. That is real money which parents throughout Australia are able to spend on things that they need for their children and that they need to look after their families. As I said, this government believes that it is important that we continue to drive economic reform, that we continue to keep unemployment low and that we continue to keep productivity strong. That is what economic reform is all about. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS
text: Order! Members may be interested to know that the young people in the gallery on my left are people who were successful in the Heywire competition that is part of the ABC's promotion of young Australians. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to them. Honourable members-Hear, hear! NA Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and relates to answers to questions she has previously given to the parliament. I refer the minister to the two Regional Partnerships grants of $748,000 each, which she approved to fund dredging the mouth of Tumbi Creek and which were announced by the member for Dobell and the Prime Minister in the lead-up to the recent federal election. Can the minister explain why the member for Dobell could announce details of the first Regional Partnerships grant of $748,000 on 8 June 2004, which was 16 days before an application was lodged and more than 24 hours before Wyong Shire Council even met to consider lodging an application?

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-We may have had a very efficient department and very scrupulous service, but I will check the facts of that matter and get back to the Labor Party. I never take what they say without notice; you cannot rely on them. Iraq

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government doing to support the Iraqis with their security? Is this in accord with the stance taken by the international community?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Fadden for his question and, indeed, his interest. Australia, as the House knows, along with the international community, warmly welcomed the elections that took place in Iraq on 30 January. As an international community, not just here in Australia, we recognise that those elections were a turning point and we now have to do everything we can to help the Iraqi people. We have an Army training team which is assisting the Iraqi army develop a sufficient logistic capability, and we have already trained up three Iraqi army battalions and the brigade headquarters staff. The Australian Federal Police are also contributing to a police training centre in Jordan. When I was in Europe last week I was very impressed by the strength of support there is now in Europe-if it had not always been the case-to do what the Europeans can to make a democratic and free Iraq work. The mood in the whole of Europe today is to get together with the United States and help the people of Iraq. The NATO Secretary General, for example, has made it perfectly clear that NATO itself is going to try to assist with the overall training task. When I was in France the French foreign minister and also the defence minister told me that France itself was playing a role in training security forces and wanted to continue to do so in an upgraded way. The German foreign minister, who has been here over the last few days, has made it perfectly clear that Germany is committed to providing training. I make the point that there are 28 countries which have some troops on the ground in Iraq. The member for Barton in an interview the other day expressed great surprise that there were so many countries there. There are others that are making contributions in different ways, and it is delightful to see the international community coming together and supporting a new, emerging democracy in Iraq and supporting a free people. Last night the Leader of the Opposition did an interview on Lateline and was asked questions about Iraq. He is only new in the job, so I think all of us would agree that we should not be too hard on him. But I thought the House might be interested in just what the Leader of the Opposition said. He said: What I'm suggesting now is that the United States should indicate to the incoming government a belief that that government should now negotiate a compromise with the Sunni forces in the country, and that the United States did not want to be drawn into the vortex of that by being readily manipulated every now and then to give the Sunnis a swat while that government sought to put a bit of extra pressure on them, and that, really, ball was now in their court, and the US wanted to get itself into a position where it was no longer the first responder in the area. I am exhausted; 106 words in one sentence, and I am not sure anybody had any idea what that sentence meant. But I believe a 106word sentence is pretty close to a record for any member of this parliament. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads and refers to the previous question we asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, about what must be the first case in recorded history where the barrel preceded the pork. I refer the minister to the $1.5 million in Regional Partnerships grants allocated to dredging open the mouth of Tumbi Creek and administered by his department. Can the minister confirm that heavy rain in October last year flushed the mouth of Tumbi Creek open by natural means? Did the Tuggerah Lakes Estuary and Coastal Management Committee, which includes representation from the Wyong Shire Council, then seek the reallocation of funding for the dredging works to other projects because the full dredging originally planned for was no longer required?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for his question. I am not surprised that the member for Dobell was out there advocating for this very important project, the dredging of Tumbi Creek, which was supported at the time by the Labor Party. Their candidate in Dobell was running around saying that this was an excellent project and that the Labor Party supported it. Yet now they are in this House saying that they do not agree with the project. The Regional Partnerships program, since it was established on 1 July 2003, has received 1,070 applications. As of 31 Decemthe ber 2004, a total of $113 million of Australian government funding has been approved for some 504 projects. Regional Partnerships is a good program. It deals with real issues, providing real benefits to the Australian public.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr speaker, I rise on a point of order. He has finished, Mr Speaker, but my point of order is on the obvious point of relevance. We want to know about the opening of the mouth of the creek. Transport: Road and Rail Infrastructure

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: 2.18 p.m.)My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister inform the House of recent developments towards providing better road and rail infrastructure throughout Australia, particularly in my home state of Victoria?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Casey for his question and acknowledge his very great interest in infrastructure in Victoria. I have to say he is not the only one. We have quite a group of people who have been very keen to see Scoresby get up and to see the national highway through the north of Victoria upgraded. Indeed, under our transport plan for the nation, AusLink, we are proposing something in the order of a 120 per cent increase in funding for Victoria alone over the next five years compared to the last five years, reflecting very real infrastructure needs up and down the east coast and in Victoria in particular. Australia does need better road and rail frastructure, but we need to ensure that we get value for money. I recorded here yesterday that I was delighted that South Australia has signed up to our construction code, and I am delighted to see too that Victoria has agreed to important industrial relations reforms, by agreeing to our industrial relations construction code objectives. That code will deliver high-quality, efficient and economical construction of major road and rail projects. It will drive taxpayers' dollars further-and that is very important. In relation to Victoria, all we need to get the ball rolling is for Victoria to sign off on the bilateral which we have been negotiating for a long time. I do not think there should be any problem there at all. Once the Victorian and South Australian governments have signed the AusLink bilateral agreements, Australian government money will flow to those very important projects right across their states. And we trust that other states will follow shortly. We trust that they will get the buzz that this is too good an opportunity to miss out on. There has been a bit of background static about Scoresby in Victoria. Let me reiterate that they have always known in Victoria that we signed an agreement that we would fund Scoresby as a freeway, not a tollway. Our money remains on the table. I want to stress that, whilst it is our position that where there was a written promise it ought to be honoured, we will not hold up AusLink in Victoria on this matter. We simply make the point: sign the bilateral and get the projects going. If you will not build a freeway for the people in that part of Melbourne, that is okay. We will not put any money towards it, but that is the no reason to hold the rest of it up. We want to get those projects going. They are important for exports, they are important for jobs, they are important for amenity and they are inimportant environmentally. I urge all states, including Victoria, to sign up so that we can get those major projects going-the sooner, the better. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: 2.21 p.m.)My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. I refer the minister to his previous answer concerning the Tumbi Creek Regional Partnerships grant. Can the minister confirm that his department told him that natural flushing of the Tumbi Creek mouth in late 2004 impacted upon the $1.5 million grant for dredging, leading to a likely reduction in the level of Commonwealth funding for the project because full dredging of the mouth was no longer required?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member opposite for his question. I can only state again what I said in answer to the previous question: Regional Partnerships is an excellent program. The dredging of Tumbi Creek was an important project, remains an important project and is a project which was supported by the Labor candidate at the last election, who was running around all over the Central Coast saying, ‘We support this project.' It an important project and it is part of a very important Australian government projectRegional Partnerships. I have nothing further to add to my previous answer. Thank you. Trade: Exports

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House of Australia's recent export performance?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. The member for Grey represents an electorate that covers a large part of South Australia, an electorate that makes a significant contribution to the economic well-being of Australia. The simple answer is that our export performance last year-in the calendar year 2004-was very good. Our exports rose, both in value terms and in volume terms. For the information of the House, in 2004 our exports rose by $11.7 billion, to finish the year at $152½ billion worth of goods and services exported out of Australia, earning much needed dollars for our economy. The growth was recorded in all sectors. Rural exports grew by 20 per cent-that is an important element of the member for Grey's constituency; resources exports increased by 13 per cent; services exports grew by 5 per cent; and manufacturing exports grew by 2 per cent. The House should recognise that, when analysing trade performance, you need to factor both merchandise and services into the equation. In volume terms exports rose by 7 per cent over the first three-quarters of last year-the figures are only available up until September. So in volume terms and value terms both merchandise and services achieved significant increases through the calendar year last year. Our export performance would be even better if our exporters did not have to deal with some industrial action taken by some of is the trade unions in Australia like the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union. It is interesting to note that in January both Toyota and Holden were forced to import automotive quality steel into Australia to keep their production lines going, because of industrial action being taken by the CEPU at BlueScope Steel. Can you believe it? Holden and Toyota were flying steel into Australia in Antonov aircraft. Our nation is the largest producer of iron ore in the world, and we are buying steel offshore to keep our manufacturing industries going. Kirby Adams, the Managing Director of BlueScope Steel, had something very instructive to say about this: It is an unfortunate truth, and not widely stated, that the irresponsible actions of a few union leaders and officials are creating real hesitation about new and large scale manufacturing investment in this country. That is not the government saying that; that is the managing director of Bluescope Steel. The Australian Labor Party should be cognisant of what industry is saying in this regard. One of the reasons our government wants to reform the Australian workplace is so that our exporters of manufactured goods are not held to ransom by militant union leaders. If the opposition wants to make a contribution to this debate they should support the government's reforms in the Australian workplace to ensure that our exporters do not have to be confronted by this. But we do know that that is probably unlikely, given that since 1995 the Australian Labor Party has received something like $3.3 million in donations from the CEPU. So, if the Labor Party want to help the manufacturing industries and help Australia's export effort, they can get the unions off the back of the manufacturers. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: 2.27 p.m.)My question is again to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. I refer the minister to his previous answer concerning the $1.5 million Regional Partnerships grant to Tumbi Creek. Can he confirm that, once he became aware of the natural flushing of the creek, his office suggested to the department that it ignore the state of the creek mouth and go ahead and pay the money anyway? Mr Crean interjecting

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I welcome the questionthe third question on this issue from the member opposite. I have been advised that a Wyong Shire Council engineer reported to Wyong council at their December meeting in 2004 that the November rain had not removed any of the sludge and that in fact the full funding and the removal of 15,000 cubic metres of sludge was necessary. Mr Crean interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Hotham is warned!

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Whilst I am on my feet, I thought the House might be interested in a brochure that was circulated in the last tion campaign by the Labor candidate for Dobell, David Mehan. The brochure has a lovely photo of David and says: Labor's candidate for Dobell, David Mehan, Labor will fund the dredging of Tumbi Creek with a commitment of $1.3 million to continue the project. I table the brochure. Industry: Building and Construction

Speaker: Mr WOOD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House of the government's progress in implementing the National Code of Practice for the Construction Industry and the implementation guidelines?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for La Trobe for his question and particularly his interest in continuing investment in the state of Victoria. The government is committed to reforming the building and construction industry to see the end of unlawful, inefficient and unproductive practices. That is why we have implemented the national code and guidelines for this $46 billion industry-to ensure that lawful practices are put in place, especially where billions of dollars of Commonwealth funding are concerned. I was, therefore, pleased that the Victorian government announced yesterday that it had agreed to implement the national code of practice for AusLink funded projects. This is a crucial element in the government's reform program to see that laws are properly observed in the commercial building and construction industry. The decision of the Victorian government follows that of another Labor state government in South Australia. I look forward now to all of the other states and territories agreeing-as both South Australia and Victoria elec- now have-to implement the code and the guidelines. I note that, for example, there is a certain political event occurring in Western Australia at the present time. This would be says an excellent opportunity for Premier Gallop to announce that Western Australia will follow the lead of both Victoria and South Australia. I hope that the other state premiers will also come on board in the near future. I and my department will continue to work constructively, as we have done with both South Australia and Victoria, to bring about this important reform. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Local Government, ritories and Roads and follows the answer he just gave referring to a December report from a city engineer. I again refer the minisfully ter to the Tumbi Creek $1.5 million Regional Partnerships grant. Is the minister aware in November last year a number of Wyong shire councillors received a warning from your office that council should not disclose the true state of the Tumbi Creek mouth to the minister's department?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question on the Tumbi Creek project. I have been a member of this House long enough to know that I should check everything that the opposition says, and I will check with my department. I want to re-emphasise that this project was subject to the standard rigorous assessment process of my department. Initially Wyong Shire Council sought $748,000 from the Regional Partnerships program. This was based on the expectation that the New South Wales Labor government would also support the project. But, when the hopes of the local residents were dashed by the Carr government, despite our commitment, we ensured that this project would proceed-and I am very pleased that we were able to ensure that the project would proceed. Health: Services

Speaker: Mrs MARKUS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House about how the government's election commitments are improving health services for all Australians?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for her question. I can tell the House that she rapidly developing the reputation as the best member Greenway has ever had. Mr Albanese interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Ter- Grayndler is warned!

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Howard government, as the member for Greenway well knows, is committed to our Medicare system and is always looking for ways to improve furthat ther the world's best health system. On 1 January, the government implemented two important election commitments. The first, ‘100% Medicare', means a $4.60 increase in the standard GP rebate. The second, Round the Clock Medicare, means a $10 loading for after-hours GP services. These commitments mean more money for GPs who bulk-bill and they mean more money in the pockets of patients whose GPs do not bulk-bill. I can inform the House that in January some six million Australians visited their GPs and took advantage of these new Howard government initiatives. That meant that GPs and their patients benefited to the tune of an additional $30 million in one month alone. Australians know that they can trust the Howard government with the Medicare system. They know that they can trust the Howard government to make a good system even better. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is again to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. I again refer the minister to the Tumbi Creek $1.5 million Regional Partnerships grant. Minister, isn't it a fact that your office told Wyong officials to cover up the true state of the Tumbi Creek and that your office wrote the following to Wyong officials, ‘Any changes mean less federal money so the Wyong officials should keep their counsel on this if we want the total is allocated by the PM to Tumbi Creek'? Minister, did your office on your behalf engage in a conspiracy to mislead about the true state of Tumbi Creek, to defraud the Commonwealth?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I think the last part of that question should be part of a substantive motion, but the first part stands.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will make further inquiries in my office to check the validity of the comments made by the Leader of the Opposition. I want to take this opportunity to ject any suggestion whatsoever of impropriety or any illegal or untoward dealings by my office. Education

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister inform the House what the Howard government is doing to raise the status of the teaching profession and improve the quality of teaching standards in Australia?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Canning for his question and I give my regards to the very high quality teachers at the Armadale school in his electorate. Apart from us, as parents, the single most important influence on the lives of our children is their teachers. They, apart from parents, most influence the educational and personal development of young Australians. This government believes that the No. 1 priority in school education in Australia is to raise the respect society has for teaching as a profession and also to ensure that the teaching profession is supported in setting and maintaining its own performance standards for both school leaders and teachers. To that end, the government has committed $10 million initially to the establishment of the National Institute for Quality Teaching and School Leadership at ANU, to both set and define nationally consistent standards for teacher education throughout Australia. In addition to that, there is a range of other initiatives, including the direct support of ongoing teacher training and $109 million, for example, for improving teacher undergraduate education and the higher education reforms. It was with a great sense of dismay and concern that I read the editorial of the Australian Association for the Teaching of English professional journal, which was published today in part on the front page of the re- Australian. The President of the New South Wales English Teachers Association, who is also the immediate past chairman of the New South Wales Board of Studies English Curriculum Committee, has written an editorial which seeks to demean and denigrate, firstly, his own colleagues in the teaching of English; secondly, the students of English throughout Australia; and, thirdly, the position of the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister personally. I will not give dignity to what has been written by repeating it in the House, but Professor Sawyer, for example, believes that we have gone beyond what he describes as ‘critical' education. He said: We are the only area of the curriculum that has all the students. We should be making a difference. And this is in an editorial that expresses a strident criticism of Australians for choosing to re-elect the Howard government late last year, bemoaning that fact. I would suggest to Professor Sawyer's colleagues that they should review his capacity to serve in any professional capacity on behalf of any teacher organisation in Australia. This also confirms what many parents suspect, and that is that a minority of teachers use the classroom to impose their own partisan political views on their students. Whether they are pro coalition or pro another party, there is no place for political cheerleading in a classroom. I would say to Professor Sawyer that just maybe he underestimates his own colleagues. Just maybe those young people who have been taught English in Australia do recognise the need for an Australian government that will protect and defend Australia's borders, that will stop people paying to get their way into Australia, that recognises the need for short-term political cost to reform Australia's tax system, to stand up against terrorism and to stand up on the side of those who seek justice throughout the world. As far as I am concerned, Professor Sawyer's colleagues and his employers should seriously review his place in any position of leadership. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is again to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. Can the minister confirm that the member for Dobell was also a party to the decision made by his office to keep quiet about the changed circumstances at Tumbi Creek which would mean that the grant previously announced by the member for the dredging of the creek mouth was no longer necessary?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No, I cannot confirm that the member for Dobell was a party to any discussions that have been brought forward today. I said that I will seek further information from my office and get back to you. Health and Ageing: Aged Care

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government's community aged care packages are helping more older Australians to remain at home?

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Bass for his question. I was most impressed with his interest in and his understanding of aged care issues in his electorate when I visited last year. Unlike Labor, the Howard government recognises that an increasing number of older Australians wish to remain at home as they age, and their families are looking for more options and more choices for their older Australians. That is why the government has increased the number of community aged care packages-that is, low-level care delivered at home-from some 4,400 packages when we first came to office to over 31,000 packages that are available for community care today. That is an increase of about 700 per cent, yet the age group over 70 has increased by only perhaps 20 per cent during that time. We have also introduced the innovative extended aged care at home packages, which are an extension of community care, to cover situations where people require high-level nursing home care but delivered at home. We will deliver on our election commitment to provide a further 2,000 extended aged care at home packages which are dementia specific-targeted for people who have specific needs because they are suffering from dementia. In relation to community care packages, in January I was delighted to announce that a further 2,818 community aged care and extended aged care at home packages were subsidised by the Australian government and allocated across Australia. In Tasmania, some 65 places were allocated, and I know the member for Bass was pleased to announce 20 places in his electorate. This government is concerned with the needs and interests of older Australians. By supporting and delivering more community aged care, we are realising our vision of a world-class system of aged care, a system that is high quality, affordable, accessible and provides choice and options for older Australians. Ministerial Code of Conduct

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that his code of ministerial conduct requires that ministers must be honest in their public dealings? Does the Prime Minister now concede that the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads has breached the code by seeking to spend taxpayers' funds despite knowing that such funds should not be spent and by seeking to cover up facts which, if exposed, would have stopped the payment? Given this blatant breach of the code of ministerial conduct, will the Prime Minister now sack the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I certainly can confirm that the ministerial code requires ministers to be honest in their dealings with the public. But I can also confirm that I do not discharge ministers on the basis of allegations from the Leader of the Opposition. A number of questions have been asked. I am unfamiliar with the detail of the issue. The minister has said that matters are going to be investigated. They will be investigated; I will expect to receive a full and prompt report of that investigation; and I will take the appropriate action if it is needed. NA GOVERNMENT, TERRITORIES AND

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: I move: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith: That this House censure the Minister for cal Government, Territories and Roads for: (1) blatantly breaching his duty to act honestly in his capacity as a Minister; (2) seeking to defraud the Commonwealth by granting $1.5 million of taxpayers' money for dredging open the mouth of Tumbi Creek despite knowing such dredging was no longer required; (3) conspiring with others to defraud the Commonwealth and specifically directing local Wyong officials who knew the truth to stay silent; and (4) covering up the fact that the mouth of the creek was open and such dredging was no longer required by directing his Department to regard the commitment by the Howard Government to the grant as non-negotiable and pay the money. We have here a serious issue for this parliament to contemplate. This is a program riddled with rorts, one after another. That will become obvious as the days of this parliament proceed. This is kleptomania dressed up in the guise of public policy on infrastructure. In this particular case, it was the barrel before the pork, because the announcement was made before any conceivable consideration of it was given by any authority. But the conclusion, the denouement, was-and I was interested because there was one piece of information that we did not have and that was revealed by the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads in his remarks here-that in December there was a statement by the city engineer in regard to the opening of the creek which followed the ROADS various instructions by the minister's office Motion to the council to change its mind and change its view. Some poor devil of a public servant in the Wyong Shire Council was dragged kicking and screaming into the conspiracy after he-no doubt the same official-had advised the councillors earlier on that they Loshould seek to redeploy those funds because they were needed elsewhere and not at the mouth of Tumbi Creek. Don't go on with this rubbish about the Labor Party supporting this. We supported this when the mouth of the creek was closed. What we are talking about is a situation where the mouth of the creek was open and what was required when the mouth of the creek was open. Two documents suffice to demonstrate the culpability in regard to this fraud. One is from Graeme Hallett, special adviser to the Hon. Jim Lloyd, corresponding with his department. This is the document that launched the conspiracy, if you like, because it is a document that flowed from knowledge coming into the minister's office, no doubt from Mr Ticehurst and others, that the council was changing its mind and wanted the money for something else-that the department was indeed recommending that something else ought to happen and that the particular grant ought not to be proceeded with. What did Mr Hallett say to Giulio, who is obviously the chap in the department who receives these things? He says: In the light of this development ... That development is the councillor's motion that ‘some recent heavy rainfall has to some extent ameliorated the environmental problem identified at Tumbi Creek' and that one councillor Graeme had ‘mooted the view that the funds could be re-allocated for other upstream bank erosion works'. What he says to this official is, ‘Change your mind on your advice.' He says: ... I require a clear statement on behalf of Commonwealth by DOTARS of the conditions that apply to the announced funding for the agreed works at Tumbi Creek for the dredging and removal to land fill of the spoil in Tumbi Creek. The commitment by the Howard Government to the electors of Dobell in partnership with Wyong Council is non negotiable. It is the tion of Mr Ticehurst that the money be delivered as agreed for the works in the schedule of the agreement under Regional Partnerships. Just to make sure that those recalcitrant councillors who had found the creek mouth open, who found the boats getting out very easily and who saw other problems around, needing less money, that the grant could be devoted to-just in case these recalcitrants did not get the message that they would get the $1.5 million no matter what-this particular missive emanated from Mr Graeme Hallett of the minister's office, no doubt in consultation with the minister. Given the minister's closeness to Mr Ticehurst, the member for Dobell, and given his proximity to his own seat in the area, the notion that he himself would not be aware of what was going on in his office is absolute nonsense, and it is an excuse we will not accept. This is the particular missive directed to Ken Ticehurst, Mayor Brenton Pavier, Councillor Greg Best, Councillor Ron Stevens, Councillor Doug Eaton and Councillor Robin Stewart: Subject: FW: Tumbi Creek project funding agreement with the Commonwealth See the response below. Any change means less federal money, so the Wyong officials should keep their counsel on this if we want the total allocated by the PM for Tumbi Creek. regards Graeme ‘Regards, Graeme' indeed! Understand the import of this. This is $1.5 million worth of the Commonwealth dough. It is $1.5 million and not $750,000 because, no matter what was said by the government of the day-or the opposition for that matter in the course of the last election campaign-the NSW government says: ‘You have got to be joking. We are not going to join in this pork-barrel paposirade, thank you very much. We are out of this.' So what happened? The Prime Minister turned up and he said in the election campaign: ‘Not only have you got the $750,000 that came through, in the first instance, from the promise of the member and was subsequently endorsed by the council, but you have got $750,000 on top of it because I, John Howard, am stepping in where Bob Carr neglectfully fears to tread. I am going to make the dough available to you all. I am going to make the $1.5 million available to you all, as it turned out, whether you need or not. We are going to rack out that $1.5 million for you and the minister's office is going to discipline any councillor or council engineer who dares reveal the fact that the mouth of the river is open, the boats are all going out and the $1.5 million might be usefully spent in smaller amounts elsewhere. That is the nub of this particular matter, but it is surrounded by the whole panoply of malpractice and impropriety that has gone into this roads project. There has been no study of any of the propositions-in this case it is announced before it is asked for. The relevant authority, being the Wyong Shire Council, who has responsibility for public works in relation to local government expenditures in the particular area, has not even thought of the darn thing. But the member for Dobell and the minister are out there making this case and the now Minister for Veterans' Affairs is out there making the nouncement. Desperately struggling to catch up is the council, 16 days later, saying: yes, we will have it. Yes, we will have the money for this please. Yes, we will have it.' And that well-known process in Minister Anderson's department of detailed consideration by departmental officials, of rigid cost-benefit analyses, of determination of what the national interest is, of fundamental research into the economic needs of the people of this area all took precisely six hours before the grant was finally ticked offimmediately approved within 24 hours of the council putting in the request for it. The simple fact of the matter is that element of this program is a disgrace-every single element of it. You know darn well that this is a multimillion dollar slush fund-tens of millions of dollars which should be spent properly on decent infrastructure projects is going down the gurgler to save a dozen National Party members and half a dozen Liberals on top of that. This government, in its it dotage, has lost its grip on what are public funds and what are theirs. It has finally got to the position where it is prepared to defraud the Commonwealth and instruct people they are to have the money whether they want it or not, simply to preserve the credibility of its members. One and a half million dollars worth of taxpayers' funds have been defrauded under the explicit instructions of the minister's office, over the objection of the minister's department and over the objection, when they were looking at it in clear-eyed fashion, of the local council. He should be censured. (Time expired)

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: Is the motion seconded?

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: I second the motion. In OctoberNovember last year, rainfall washed out the Tumbi Creek mouth. That creek is still flowing freely and local fishers have access to an- Tuggerah Lake. Silt that was blocking the creek mouth has been naturally washed on to ‘Oh, the floor of Tuggerah Lake with no obvious detrimental environmental impact. Following the rain, the Tuggerah Lakes Estuary and Coastal Management Committee, comprising Wyong Shire Council, New South Wales government and community representatives, heard that Tumbi Creek was open and sought the reallocation of funding for the dredging works. A motion was put to the next Wyong Shire Council meeting in similar terms. As Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, Minister Lloyd has the authority to make decisions about the allocation of every funding under the Regional Partnerships program. He also holds an electorate adjacent to Dobell. While these initial grants were approved by Minister Kelly-Calamity De-Anne

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: Order! The member will withdraw that expression.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: I withdraw it. The opposition has obtained emails from Graeme Hallet, the special adviser to Minister Lloyd, demonstrating a very close involvement in the progress of the project in late 2004. Following the rain, Mr Hallett wrote to Giulio Cerasani, the DLO for Parliamentary Secretary Cobb, requiring a statement from the Department of Transport and Regional Services about the conditions of the Regional Partnerships grant: ... for the information of Wyong elected councillors and senior officers, so there can be no doubt about the way forward to deliver the commitment on Tumbi Creek. This email was prompted by a notice of motion before Wyong Shire Council noting the natural flushing of the creek mouth and seeking the redirection of funds to other projects. Mr Hallett made a suggestion to the department in the following terms: The commitment by the Howard Government to the electors of Dobell, in partnership with Wyong Council is non negotiable. It is the position Ticehurst that the money be delivered as agreed for the works in the schedule of agreement under Regional Partnerships. In other words: never mind the rain, just pay the money anyway. It gets even worse. In an email obtained by the opposition, the department told Mr Hallett that it was waiting for advice from Wyong Shire Council about the state of the creek mouth and, subject to that advice, contemplating a reduced Commonwealth contribution. Mr Hallett forwarded a copy of the department's advice, which was presumably intended solely for him in his capacity as special adviser, to the member for Dobell and the Wyong Shire Council's non-Labor councillors, including the Liberal mayor, and issued the following warning: Any changes means less federal money, so the Wyong officials should keep their counsel on this if we want the total allocated by the PM for Tumbi Creek. The Wyong mayor sent a note to two other councillors seeking to have that notice of motion changed, with the message: ‘no doubt you would be aware of the letter from DOTARS that has been emailed to us.' This special adviser to Minister Lloyd was telling the Wyong Shire Council to keep their traps shut. You may remember that John Cleese's character Basil Fawlty became famous for saying, ‘Don't mention the war.' Mr Hallett was saying, ‘Don't mention the rain.' The message for Wyong council was: ‘Don't come back to us saying we don't need to flush the creek anymore, because you'll lose the money if you do.' This amounts to a conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth to hand over taxpayers' money under false pretences. The minister should be censured and the people of Australia need to be provided with a full account of the roles that this minister and the member of Mr for Dobell have played in this conspiracy. It is bad enough and farcical enough that Minister Kelly was prepared to approve these grants and announce these allocations even before an application had been made to her. Even worse is that this minister and the member for Dobell want that money to be paid, even though the rain has ensured that the project is no longer needed. Let me conclude by paraphrasing a well-known nursery rhyme: The member for Dobell climbed up the Tumbi spout. Down came the rain and washed the silt right out. Out came Jim Lloyd's office to dry up all the rain. And they all climbed into the regional rorts trough once again!

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL
text: Members opposite are making a very serious charge. Let us not underestimate the seriousness of the charge that members opposite are making. They are making the very serious charge that a minister in this government, his office and another member of this government have attempted, in effect, to defraud the Commonwealth. It is a very serious charge, and it should not be made without very strong evidence. I have listened to the extracts that have been read the House by the Leader of the Opposition and by the member for Wills. All I can hear in the extracts from those emails is evidence that this is a government that does not renege on its commitments. That is the evidence that I have heard given to this House. I have not heard any evidence of any attempt to defraud the Commonwealth or of any conspiracy to do anything other than deliver on a commitment that this government made-a commitment which, I remind members opposite, was supported by them. Challenged by members opposite, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads did absolutely the right thing. He said he would check the record with his department and with his office. That is precisely what a minister of the Crown should do when confronted with the kind of questioning that members opposite have subjected him to today. Members opposite could have waited for this minister, this good and decent man, to come back having checked the record. But no, they are not prepared to do that at all. They have jumped the gun. They have leapt into typical opposition tactics of smearing without substance, of rushing in with the most serious allegations, which certainly are not proven on the basis of the emails that have been selectively read to this House by the Leader of the Opposition. Let us examine again exactly what the Leader of the Opposition is putting to this House. He is putting to this House not just that the minister, the minister's office or the member for Dobell have done the wrong thing but that Wyong council-not just councillors but the professional staff of Wyong council-have engaged in a grand conspiracy to try to defraud the Commonwealth of money that Wyong council did not need. I remind members opposite of the material to that the minister presented today to the House from the Wyong shire engineer, from December, which said that this dredging was still required. For the charge of the members opposite to be sustained, that professional officer of Wyong council would have to have been engaging in a conspiracy of deception and a conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth. It is a very serious charge to make against a professional. Let us rue the day that the Leader of the Opposition can come into this House and make that kind of allegation without substantial evidence to back it up, because it is a very serious smear not just against politicians or members of the government but against a professional officer of a New South Wales council. I hope he has the evidence. On the basis of what he has said today in this House, he does not have the evidence. Let me remind members opposite that this grant that they are now so opposed to was something that they entirely supported during the election campaign. Let me remind members opposite that they supported during the election campaign a series of grants that they now claim to be corrupt pork-barrelling. There is not a single grant made under the Regional Partnerships program that members opposite criticised at the time those grants were announced. I challenge the Leader of the Opposition: if he is serious about his current contempt for the Regional Partnerships program, can he give us one example, just one, of a Regional Partnerships grant announced during the election that he and his team opposed? He will not be able to do it, because these were all perfectly reasonable grants made on a perfectly reasonable basis. Members opposite are waxing indignant about grants made by this government under the Regional Partnerships program. Let me remind the House of some of the grants that would have been made by the opposition had they won the election. These are some of the grants that were promised by members of the opposition. I challenge members of the opposition to produce any scientific study, any serious cost-benefit analysis or any profound detailed examination of the promises that they made during the election campaign. Let me name just a few of them. There was $1 million for a national centre of democracy at the Eureka Centre in Ballarat. Where was the cost-benefit analysis for that? What rigorous examination did this grant announcement go through? There was $10 million for a national museum of Indigenous culture in Cairns. Again, where was the rigorous analysis? To what scrutiny was this promise subjected? Listen to this one. This was announced by the then Leader of the Opposition on 9 September: $1 million to whichever entity took over the vacant Austoft site in Bundaberg. They did not care who got the money; they just wanted to give the money to someone. There was $1.5 million to a turtle interpretation centre, $3 million for sporting complexes at Thuringowa and $6 million to upgrade the Rockhampton Showgrounds. For all I know, they might be quite worthy projects. But the fact is that they were made by the opposition without any serious examination, and the opposition has the cheek and the hide to come into this chamber and condemn this government up hill and down dale for making grants under a perfectly regular federal government program which has gone through the usual kind of scrutiny that federal government program grants have applied to them. The Regional Partnerships program has been perfectly, competently and properly administered by the Public Service of this country and by the government of Australia. Allegations of political bias simply do not hold up to scrutiny. The reason why-and it is quite simple-the majority of funds went to coalition electorates is because we have the majority of electorates. If members opposite won more seats, they could expect to get more money under programs such as Regional Partnerships. The fact is that, of the applications for Regional Partnerships funding, 78 per cent of those applications in Labor and Independent electorates were approved. Members on this side of the House have some reason to be disappointed-only 77 per cent of applications in coalition electorates were approved. This is a good government administering a reasonable and necessary program to put the heart and soul back into country Australia. By contrast, it is the same tired old opposition, the same stale faces, spouting the same old message that we got before Christmas time. Latham has gone, but Labor has not changed. Not only that, the member for Brand has not changed-it is still the same old histrionic style that the Australian people have heard so often before and rejected so often before. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: NOES
text: Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. NA Parliamentary Services: Hansard

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I refer you to page 587 of House of Representatives Practice, from which I quote: Hansard is issued in two editions. There is a daily proof issue available the day after the proceedings to which it refers, and a weekly final issue from which the permanent volumes are compiled. It then goes on to say: Control over the published content of the Hansard reports of the House resides in the House itself. Mr Speaker, when today I sought to exercise my inalienable right to bring a printed copy of yesterday's daily proof into the chamber, I was told that there was no such proof available. My attention was drawn to a memo from the Secretary of the Department of Parliamentary Services dated 7 February, which indicated that the daily Proof Hansard circulation would be limited and which excludes members of this House; that hard copies of weekly official Hansards would cease production; and that bound volumes of the official Hansards would continue to be produced. The memo, Mr Speaker, asserts that that was done with your authority. I might have missed something, but I am not aware that members were consulted about this. It is certainly the case that the House itself was not. From a personal point of view, I have no objection to weekly editions not being circulated-they can be accessed electronically for historical purposes-and I certainly regard the expensive bound copies as an indulgence, and they should certainly cease. But I do object personally, very strongly, to not being able to bring a printed copy of the Hansard daily proof into this House, because the day after is the day on which proceedings from the previous day are relevant. One obvious example is that those people on the front bench do not have access to the electronic data. Mr Speaker, I would like you to respond to that, and I seek from you an assurance that those members of this House who wish to have a printed copy of the daily Hansard will continue to have that available to them in accordance with the usual practice.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the honourable member for Perth. I would make several points on this. I am certainly sympathetic to his views, to start with. Secondly, I would point out that there are copies of the Hansard available here in the chamber. If those prove insufficient, there will be more. The next point, of course, is that copies can be taken off the parliamentary net, so they are available in that form. There was a letter circulated to inform honourable members about this. I have in fact already had some discussions about this, but I am happy to seek and will be seeking further responses from members on that point. Mr Stephen Smith- Mr Speaker, while you are doing that and seeking responses, I wonder whether you could indicate whether the previous practice will continue until you have considered those responses?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Can I clarify with the honourable member for Perth which practice he is talking about? Mr Stephen Smith-I think, Mr Speaker, that there are more than 10 members of the House who would like to have the daily printed copy available to them.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: The daily Hansard is the one you are referring to. Yes, I will certainly pursue that matter for you. Questions in Writing

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Lowe and I will pursue that matter for him. MEMBER FOR HUNTER: DISSENT NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: FROM RULING
text: On 9 December last year, the member for Hunter asked me a question concerning events the previous day during a motion of dissent from a ruling of the Deputy Speaker. The member for Hunter suggested that comments made by the Deputy Speaker constituted an intervention in debate on the motion of dissent. I have consulted the relevant Hansard and commissioned research into similar situations. House of Representatives Practice indicates, at page 565, that words critical of the character or conduct of a person-and this includes members of the House-whose actions can only be challenged by means of a substantive motion should not be included in the terms of a matter of public importance. The serious nature of such challenges is emphasised by the fact that a substantive motion allows the House to vote on such actions. A matter of public importance does not provide opportunity for the House to come to a decision by a vote. The terms of the matter approved for discussion on 8 December did not specifically identify any persons. However, when matters of this kind are being discussed by the House, it is not in order to make comments that are critical, in a personal sense, of individuals during the course of the discussion. Matters such as that proposed for discussion on 8 December tend to provide challenges for self-discipline by members of the House. When this self-discipline is absent, it is incumbent upon the occupant of the chair to intervene. This has been the situation for some time, as indicated by the Hansard of 9 April 1974 in respect of Deputy Speaker Scholes, and of 28 November 1995 in respect of Deputy Speaker Jenkins. On 8 November, on more than one occasion the Deputy Speaker requested the member addressing the House to desist from the terms he was using in speaking to the matter of public importance. The Deputy Speaker then ordered the member to resume his seat when he persisted. I believe that there were a number of options available to the Deputy Speaker in a situation that could have been construed as defiance of the chair, including naming and subsequent suspension of the member, and ordering the member to withdraw from the chamber for an hour. In withdrawing the member's call to talk on the matter, the Deputy Speaker could be seen to have applied a less harsh option. In relation to the specific question put to me by the member for Hunter, I believe that, on a rigid application of the standing orders and House of Representatives Practice, the Deputy Speaker was not required to accept the motion of dissent stemming from his requirement for the member for Wills to resume his seat. Following the moving of the motion of dissent by the then Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Speaker, in making the statement which forms the substance of the member for Hunter's complaint, was simply placing before the House a summary of the statement on the practice of the House that he had made during the comments made by the member for Wills-namely, that it was not in order, in addressing a matter of public importance, to make personal reflections on and imputations against a member of the House in the absence of a substantive motion. The Deputy Speaker thus provided the House with a succinct statement of the proposition on which it was going to be asked to vote on the motion of dissent. This was an appropriate course of action, in my opinion. NA
